charity.name: Oxfam
owner: Ollie, Graham, Tai and Barry... Team name: Just do it! It's only 100km!
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

On July 14/15 Ollie, Graham, Tai and Barry (Team name: Just do it! It's only 100km!)  will be hiking 100km in under 30 hours, across the South Downs in an effort to raise money for Oxfam.

You'll see our team fundraising target on the right. Your donation can really help us smash this goal and will be much appreciated.

This 100km Trailwalker challenge involves starting in the early hours of Saturday morning and walking continuously, through day and night, until we smash it to the finish line before midday on Sunday.

Please help us by donating! Not only will your support give us a greater sense of pride, motivation and achievement, but it will have an even greater impact on the fantastic causes that we are raising money for. 

Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust

Oxfam, fighting to beat poverty on a global scale; and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, supporting ex-servicemen and their families of Nepal, are the event charities, and ones that we are hoping to raise money and awareness for and to support their fantastic work.

For more information on these fantastic causes please go to [ https://www.oxfam.org.uk/ and/or https://www.gwt.org.uk/ ]. 

Please read below for 11 Facts About Global Poverty. 

Massive thank you's in advance. 

Ollie, Graham, Tai, Barry


11 Facts About Global Poverty:

1.    
Nearly 1/2 of the world’s population — more than 3 billion people — live on less than $2.50 a day. More than 1.3 billion live in extreme poverty — less than $1.25 a day.

2.    
1 billion children worldwide are living in poverty. According to UNICEF, 22,000 children die each day due to poverty.

3.    
805 million people worldwide do not have enough food to eat. Food banks are especially important in providing food for people that can’t afford it themselves. Run a food drive outside your local grocery store so people in your community have enough to eat.

4.    
More than 750 million people lack adequate access to clean drinking water. Diarrhoea caused by inadequate drinking water, sanitation, and hand hygiene kills an estimated 842,000 people every year globally, or approximately 2,300 people per day.

5.     In 2011, 165 million children under the age 5 were stunted (reduced rate of growth and development) due to chronic malnutrition.

6.     Preventable diseases like diarrhoea and pneumonia
take the lives of 2 million children a year who are too poor to afford proper treatment.

7.    
As of 2013, 21.8 million children
under 1 year of age worldwide had not received the three recommended doses of vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis.

8.    
1/4 of all humans live without electricity — approximately 1.6 billion people.

9.    
80% of the world population lives on less than $10 a day.

10.
Oxfam estimates that it would take $60 billion annually to end extreme global poverty--that's less than 1/4 the income of the top 100 richest billionaires.

11. The World Food Programme says, “The poor are hungry
and their hunger traps them in poverty.” Hunger is the number one cause of death in the world, killing more than HIV/AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis combined.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
In just under two weeks’ time myself, two friends and the guy who suggested this insane challenge will be starting our 100km trek across the South Downs from Petersfield to Brighton. To put that into perspective it is just under two and a half marathons.  I’m not a walker and have never done a marathon, but despite this naively thought it would just be a nice but long stroll with friends. Now having done a few training walks it is clear that this will be a serious mental and physical challenge, particularly as it has to be completed in under 30 hours. 

This event is an Oxfam event organised by the Queen's Gurkha Signals and we are seeking to raise £1,400 between us to help fight poverty. If anyone can spare a £1 or more that would be greatly appreciated!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
To celebrate my 13 year anniversary with my dearest Jo Bayles I've signed myself up to a 100K walk in under 30 hours across the South Downs. Four of us have formed Team Gout with Bayles as our support. She will be on hand to motivate, feed & water us, do foot soaks & sock changes & most importantly sort blisters & chaffing. I really wanted to spoil her to celebrate our years together.

Seriously though, me & the boys wanted to give ourselves a goal, something to work towards and we rather like walking so this challenge seemed perfect.  We've been training hard for a good few months now, walking everywhere we possibly can, dedicating weekends to training. We are under no illusions, it's going to be tough. Setting off at 7:30am Saturday, walking continuously through the night until some time Sunday morning. It'll certainly be a test. 

As well as a personal challenge we are raising money for worldwide poverty and a group of people who have given so much for our country for not much in return - Oxfam & The Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Anything you can spare towards this cause would be hugely appreciated.

Long Man x

attribution: Amy, James W, James G, Steve, Ruth, Veronica, Panda, & Support Team of Dawn, Zoe, Andy and Mike
charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my fundraising page and for your donation.

Brief Gurkha Event History:
The original challenge began in 1981 by the Queens Gurkha Signals as part of their recruitment selection training exercise and In 1986, teams of civilians were allowed to take part and Oxfam Hong Kong was invited to co-organise the event.

In 1997, with the handover of Hong Kong to China, the Gurkha regiments were relocated to the United Kingdom and the Trailwalker event followed the Gurkha's relocation and was organised over the South Downs in Sussex, with Oxfam in the UK acting as partner since 2002, alongside the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

The Event:
Last year the Gurkha's celebrated 200 years as part of the British Army and will again be supporting Oxfam to host Trailwalker, which is the ultimate physical and mental challenge. As a team each individual will need to motivate and encourage one another from start to finish to complete the challenge.

The event involves a team of four people walking 100km across the South Downs from Queens Elizabeth Country Park near Petersfield to Brighton Racecourse in less than 30 hours to help raise the funds which are split between Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust (GWT).

The Gurkha Welfare Trust:
The GWT does such good work for former members of the Brigade of Gurkhas who have historically been such fine servants of the British armed forces. Education is a fundamental part of the trust's development work. The trust has invested nearly £4 million in school builds and refurbishments over the past 25 years.

Oxfam:
Oxfam is a global movement of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. It's an injustice which can, and must, be overcome. To spread that change and make it last, political solutions are also needed to tackle the root causes of poverty and create societies where empowered individuals can thrive.

Please help me to raise some much needed funds for supporting Oxfam and former and future members of the Brigade of Gurkha's during the bicentennial anniversary of their historic involvement with the British Army.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am taking part in the 2018 Trailwalker challenge, 100km walk/run/crawl across the South Downs. In aid of Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

﻿The reason the Gurkha Welfare Trust holds a special place in mine and my family's hearts is that my late Grandfather served as an officer in the Gurkha's during WWII. Based on some of the war time stories he told me, I'm pretty sure that he wouldn't have survived the war without the dedication and bravery of the Gurkha's.

﻿The Gurkha Welfare Trust was founded in 1969, when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age. Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in WWII and other conflicts. For almost 50 years the Trust has provided welfare to enable these Gurkha veterans, their dependants and their communities to live their lives with dignity. The core of the Trust's work has always been the Welfare Pension, which is currently distributed to over 5,500 brave Gurkha veterans and widows.

On the 14th July, we will be setting off on a 100 Km trek across the south coast... the aim... mere completion.

Our story: A couple of local rugby allstars; a city slicker; and a posh guy from Bath... With a combined walking history of a trip to the coop on a sunday, a plethora of unexplored compass and map reading skills, and the determination of something that gives up relatively easily... story:
We will take it! 5/8/18

Me and my fellowship have taken on the huge burden of destroying the One ring. We will be tackling the Coast to Coast Walk with Sauron's watchful eye upon us and his minions not too far behind us. The walk is 192 miles and we will be living off ration packs as well as a nibble of the fine lembas bread before leave. Each night we will camp and tell tales, we will walk amongst the animals and fly amongst the birds (we have no fear). We need to sneak into Mordor (Robin hood bay) so that we can then cast The One Ring Into the fires of Mount Doom (the waters of The North Sea). The quest must be completed within 9-10 days, It can be done! This will be challenging and a journey I'm most certainly looking forward to. Any donations would be highly appreciated. 

May Gandalf guide us

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi Everyone, 

Lets talk about a challenge!

On 15th July 2018, myself and three team mates will be walking 100 Kilometers to raise money and awareness for Oxfam UK and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Oxfam Trailwalker begins at Queen Elizabeth Country Park passes through stunning but challenging terrain of South Downs National Park and finishes at Brighton Racecourse.

Teams of four enter this event and have 30 hours to walk or run the 100 km trail, although our team is hoping to finish within 20 hours. It’s very likely that we’ll walk through the night (with little or no sleep) until the end. The event raises vital funds for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Gurkha welfare trust is a charity that provides financial, medical and community aid to ex-Gurkha servicemen and their communities in Nepal.

My team "GasPanic" is hoping to raise funds to help some of the world’s poorest people. Our fundraising campaign will also enable Oxfam to respond immediately to emergencies around the world, as well as to fight poverty at its roots by campaigning  against injustice and empowering people with life-changing projects.

On a personal note my dad (Gurkha Major Karnasher Tamang) had taken part in the first ever trailwalker here in the UK (as he was the Gurkha Major at that time) he made it happen bringing the event from Hong Kong...

So this is personal as I need to beat his time!!! Haha

So please help it’s for a good cause... raising funds for our Gurkha Veterans (Gurkha Welfare Trust)...

My Trailwalker team members and I will be going the distance and we hope that you can support us in this massive challenge. Please consider how you may be able to get behind us, either by donating us or sharing our journey with your contacts in social media. If you would like to support us then please find more information about our goals and activities on this page and where to donate for this good cause.

100 km is a long way to walk! But putting ourselves through months of intense training will be worth it for the impact our fundraising has on others through Oxfam & The Gurkha Welfare trust. Your support is what will take me and my teammates over that finish line.

We ask you to please give generously and consider that your donation will make a real difference. 

Thank you!


Kabir

------------------------------------------------------------


Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Please support us with this huge challenge to complete 'Trailwalker 2018’' and walk/run 100km in under 30 hours. In return you will help to raise money for some fantastic causes 'The Gurkha Wefare Trust and Oxfam'. This event takes place on July 14th where we will walk through the day and night along the very hilly South Downs covering the distance of 100km from Petersfield to Brighton.  Your sponsorship will provide some very needed encouragement. 


Why??

It is realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their dependants or widows in Nepal faced destitution in old age. Many of these soldiers had served in the World Wars. However, they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an Army Pension.
Unlike their British counterparts who could rely on the Welfare State in old age, the Nepali Gurkhas had no such safety net.

Nepal remains one of the poorest countries in the world, with limited industry, agriculture and infrastructure.
It suffers from a complex terrain and climate, with frequent natural disasters. It also lacks effective public services or social welfare systems.
Today, the Trust provides financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities.
Its support is critical for ex-servicemen and their dependants, who are often unable to work through age, illness or injury. The Trust’s Welfare Pension is often all that stands between an ex-Gurkha and destitution.

Please give whatever you can, it will all help.

Thank you

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Whoever it was that coined the phrase 'there's no such thing as bad publicity', clearly hadn't anticipated the furore surrounding Oxfam at the moment. While the actions of those few workers are unacceptable, the charity had has thousands of cancellations of donations. What is not being mentioned in the media is the vast amount of amazing work that has been carried out by Oxfam, and it is that work, and the lives of those positively affected by it, that is at risk now. That's why I am cycling the Ride London 100 mile sportive in aid of Oxfam. 

Please look beyond the media headlines at the moment, and see all the incredible work being carried out by amazing volunteers, and help to make difference by donating to this page.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. So far there has been lots and lots of walking but little by me of fundraising...nothing is ever too late and I'm now springing into action. 

Sally got us joined to a WhatsApp chat one day about the idea of tackling the Trailwalker Challenge. At the time I really didn't appreciate quite how far 100km is and agreed to join the team without a second thought. 

Training is well under way for the BIG event itself on 14th-15th July 2018. Some of the training walks have really not been fun at all with loads of rain and mud. So far, I've only managed 30km in one go  ...I now realise the enormity of the task ...and so do my poor feet !!! 

The challenge is for us to complete 100KM across the South Downs in under 30 hours as a team of four! The Queen's Gurkhas can complete this course is about 9 hours... reckon it may take us a couple more than them!! ... We've been told there will be a Queen's Gurkhas curry waiting for us at the end. There had better be !!!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

During a trek around the welsh coast with Ollie.B, Ben Baker & George the 10th Somebody suggested that it would be a good idea to set ourselvs a challenge (George!) so after a few phone calls, a signing up fee and a X on the calendar, the wheels were set in motion to walk 100k in 30 hours! Since that time I’ve taken on a tough training program which includes walking to the shop at least once a week and my local pub at least twice a week! The next four weeks will be head down and train hard to get into shape for this event. knowing that people are behind us with sponsors it will give us the drive and motivation to complete this as a team effort even if it means crawling across the finish line!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In Christmas of 2013 Foreign Concept, Stray and Xtrah got their heads  together and decided that rather than let some sought after unreleased music sit idle on their hard drives they would put it to use and offer people the chance to download the tracks whilst raising money for charity. 

This year Foreign Concept has gone one step further and we at Critical have all gone through the vaults and put an album together, again for a good cause. This time we have chosen Oxfam. Oxfam is a vibrant global movement of dedicated people fighting poverty. From saving lives and developing projects that put poor people in charge of their lives and livelihoods, to campaigning for change that lasts.

All monies go directly to the charity.  

Please give generously and enjoy the music!

Merry Christmas from all at Critical Music x

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The Oxfam Trailwalker UK is a gruelling test of endurance and teamwork:  4 people, running/walking 100km in 30 hours or less along the South Downs Way.  This means they will be walking in sun, heat, cold and wet, ascending the equivalent of two Ben Nevis along the way. 

Fellowes Europe has seen several teams from France and Spain participate in their local Oxfam Trailwalker events over the past several years. This year, four brave souls from the UK have taken up the mantle and are participating in the Trailwalker event held here in the UK.  

We have set a big target for them to reach - to match their challenge!  Please donate what you can - every penny and pound will help them toward their goal! 

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
A team of four of us are hiking 100km in less than 30 hours to raise money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. We felt like this was going to be a one-off mega challenge that will take us to (and beyond) our limits. Somebody also mentioned 'Gurkha Curry' to me, so I signed up immediately!!

We will be supported by the fantastic crew of Gary Mitchell and Colin Temple. They will drive a support vehicle and meet us at checkpoints throughout the event - supplying us with hot food, restocking our water, giving us a morale boost, handing us spare socks and force-feeding us high-sugar bars of chocolate oaty joy... This will be essential if we are to complete this challenge!

Please donate to help these two fantastic organisations. Incredible work done by both every day of every year. My target is £500, but as a team we hope to raise £2000! Every penny/tenner helps!!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
hi Everyone

It's been a while since I last did a ride for charity and this year I plan to do the Ride Surrey London on behalf of Oxfam.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty for everyone. They can take on the big issues that keep people poor - like inequality, hunger and climate change. 

They haven't had the best of times recently, which they are trying to sort out, however they still bring a lot of help to a lot of people.

So if you can, please sponsor me... 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi all,

I'm riding London Prudential to raise money for Oxfam, a charity I have been passionate about for almost a decade. Like everyone, I was shocked by the revelations about abuse committed by former members of the charity in Haiti and other countries, and I believe that the charity could have done more at the time to investigate the individuals. However, my faith in Oxfam as a force for good in the world is unshaken. They are the largest, and by many measures the most effective development NGO in the world. Their projects have a positive impact on millions of lives across dozens of countries. These are the people who will suffer as Oxfam loses considerable amounts of its funding. 

I've been in training for the past 2 months, cycling c. 50 miles a week to work and back with a few long rides out of London. I'm aiming to raise £200 and to complete the course in 7 hrs (averaging approx 15 mph). I've raised £100 already with a world cup sweepstake and a bake sale at work. Thank you so much to those of you who've already supported me and been out with me on my training rides!

Those of you who'd like to track me on the day, you can do so here using my name or bib number (15377) - http://results.prudentialridelondon.co.uk/2017/?pid=tracking

Thanks so much for reading, stay tuned for more before race day! (Sunday 29 July)

G

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 29th of July I plan to ride the Prudential Ride London-Surrey 100. A sort of 100 mile London marathon for cyclists that's based on the route of the 2012 Olympic road race and gives us normal folks a rare opportunity to ride on traffic free, closed roads pretending to be Sir Brad.

Held every year since 2013 it's become  a right of passage for the MAMIL and thus massively popular, so much so that general places are awarded through a ballot system. Every year since 2013 I've entered and failed to win a place so decided this year to guarantee an entry by raising money for a charity 

So why Oxfam? I realise they wouldn't be everyones first choice given the recent revelations and I ask myself the same question but in our world of affluence (£1k+ bicycles ;-)) it can be easy to forget half the world live on less than £3 per day and many do still benefit from their work. We can only hope that it was a few bad apples and that with the removal of those responsible and recently announced changes in leadership they'll continue in the assisting of those in need rather than the exploitation. In all honesty they required the lowest commitment but surely any money to charity is better than none?

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
This year I'm riding the Prudential Ride London-Surrey 100. It starts in Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park and follows a 100-mile route on closed roads through London and into Surrey’s  countryside finishing at the Mall, by Buckingham Palace.

It's a truly spectacular event.

I am hoping that while I'm cycling, I'll be raising some money for Oxfam.

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich of resources, poverty isn't inevitable.

When disaster strikes Oxfam is there to start saving lives, then to help people come back stronger.

Every donation they receive, regardless of how big or small it is, makes a difference. They can't do it without us. 


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the Oxfam.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
On 14 July Pete Tomsett, Judith Elevique, Mike Axtell and Lorna Sutton will be taking part in a 100km trek across the South Downs to raise money for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust.  We will be part of three teams alongside  FRP Advisory and this will be
the 11th year that a team from Barclays and FRP have taken part.

The Trailwalker is the ultimate teamendurance event.  The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across theSouth Downs in under 30 hours in a team of four with a support crew.  This year we will be supported by, among others by Julie Colgan and Lisa Westwick.

The Walkers:

Judith : “This will be the fourthtime that I’ve taken part in this event, it’s tough but very rewarding! I’m looking forward to this year’s challenge and to raising money for twoextremely deserving charities”

Lorna : “This will be my first Trailwalker event and although a keen rambler, this will be the first time doing anything like this distance in one sitting. I’m really looking forward to testing my endurance alongside a great team in aid of two wonderful charities.”

Mike : “‘This will be the first time that I have taken part in the event and I am really looking forward to the challenge and knowing that the funds that we raise will go to two fantastic charities”

Julie : “This is my third time in the Support Crew.  It’s an amazing event and we meet some great people along the way.  Good luck to all our walkers this year, I’m praying that the sun is shining.”

Lisa : "Looking forward to supporting the team and being a part of this worthy event”

The charities:

The Gurkha Welfare Trust - The Trust was founded in 1969 when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age.  Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in the Second World War and other conflicts however, they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an Army pension.  For almost 50 years the Trust has provided welfare to enable these Gurkha veterans, their dependents and their communities to live their lives with dignity.  The core of the Trust’s work has always been the Welfare Pension which is currently distributed to over 5,500 brave Gurkha veterans and widows.

Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world.  The charity provides humanitarian response to emergencies such as the Ebola crisis providing life-saving essentials like safe water and hygiene kits.  It funds long-term work that allows local people to use their own ideas and skills tofight poverty in their communities and campaigns for real lasting change.

Thank you for your support.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My team and I have been training for Trailwalker for several months, and have done some gruelling practice treks on various terrains and in all sorts of weather! The 100km distance is daunting, but hopefully, with lots of support along the way from our own support team and the fantastic volunteers and Gurkhas who run the checkpoints, we will stay physically and mentally strong enough to finish!

We would be eternally grateful for any donation, however small - it all adds up! Both the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam are worthy charities, and we would like to raise as much as we can.

Thank you so much! Ruth xxx

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The event HAS been cancelled BUT we’re so stupid that we're doing it anyway. Please make donations to our Royal Marsden Charity page as below 
https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/Andrew-Manley2?utm_medium=email&utm_source=ExactTarget&utm_campaign=20180608_114292

You may have thought we'd lost our senses last year by doing the Gurkha Challenge, well, to prove you right we're doing it again, in July (even though it's cancelled)

It is a challenge which is why we don't mind harassing friends for sponsorship. For Drew in particular this is a poignant event this time, following the death of his very good friend John Millar, legendary walker, good egg and original Wingnut's support crew. We are raising money separately for the Royal Marsden Cancer Charity in his memory and for other friends, as well as the above two causes.

The team this time comprises Andrew, Graham, Bara and Giles; it represents Andrew's fourth time over the course. He said "never again" after last year but in honour of John has said "well one last time!". Graham said "once is enough" last year and Bara and Giles just didn't know what they were letting themselves in for! There is no guarantee that our team of 4 will all finish, Andrew hasn’t managed to finish with a full team yet.

There is also no guarantee that we’ll finish with all our toe nails, Andrew lost 5 last year and I lost 3, did we mention that Bara, Giles?

Anything you can spare in sponsorship will be greatly appreciated.

Thank you, Millar's Wingnuts

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Half marathons? No problem!  But walking near on non-stop 100kms, day & night, in less than 30 hours across the South Downs!  Please encourage & let us know we're not attempting the impossible by making a donation here on our JustGiving page. Any donation, however small is welcomed. We're part of a wider team which collectively is aiming to raise £2800 for Oxfam & the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

We've been completing training walks over the last 6 months, come snow or heat-wave. In all honesty we're very nervous about the real event, as that'll be the full 100km, not just the 32kms we've completed on training walks! Another unknown for us is the "all through the night" aspect! This is so very different from an "over & done with in 2 hours" half marathon & we honestly don't know how we'll fair!

Donating here through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to Oxfam. It honestly is the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for Oxfam.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
***Walking 100kms in under 30 hours on the South Downs....Are we crazy or are we crazy!?!?!***

To put into context, this challenge is the equivalent of walking 3 marathons back-to-back with the ascent/descent of Ben Nevis and Snowdon combined. 

I have been in training for the last 6 months in preparation for this event and as you may know I have been doing a LOT of walking!!! Which also includes a lot of hobbling, losing toe nails and bursting those horrid blisters! I have endured all kinds of aches and pains as well as chaffing, sunburn, bites, rashes - all in places I did not know existed! Over this time I've been cold, hot, very wet, very dry, running, limping, happy and cursing. 

Whilst I am a little nervous and still not quite sure how I will walk 100kms,  I always assume the motto "Feel the fear and do it anyway". I know that this will most definitely be a once-in-a-lifetime challenge!! 

This is also most definitely for a worthy cause and it will be your very kind donations that push me along each and every kilometre to that very-distant finish line!! Every penny helps me and more importantly Oxfam/Gurkhas, so please donate what you can! 

Thank you so much, it really is very much appreciated. Amy xxx

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Trailwalker is billed as the ultimate team endurance event. The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km (60miles) across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, supported by our own support crew and the Queen's Gurkha Signals. Training has already begun!

Our teams have pledged to raise at least £1,400 each for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of our challenge. We would love to raise much more than that!


Established in 1969, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. They achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

Oxfam are one of the world's leading providers of humanitarian aid in emergencies with recognised technical expertise in clean water, public health, food security and the protection of civilians.

Every member of Teams Totally Logic and Madness! are in no doubt that this challenge is going to be like nothing we have ever completed before! Your support to help us achieve our fundraising target will be really appreciated and help us keep putting one foot in front of the other when the going gets tough. Thank you!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
On 14th/15th July 2018, I will be taking part in Trailwalker 2018, walking non-stop 100km (60miles) , in less than 30 hours, from Petersfield to Brighton, along the tough South Downs Way, as a team of 4 walkers, along with 400 other teams, to raise money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Trust.

Although a runner, I have been out of action this year for 3 months, and only able to get back to training recently, so this particular challenge will be tough. My target is to raise £500 for these charities, please could you be generous and sponsor me, thanks.

Each teams will take on 100km of the South Downs Way, helping to end poverty with each step. The money raised will be used by Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust to improve lives around the world.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years we've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in
providing shelter, food and protection. Oxfam - When an emergency happens, Oxfam is there to respond. We have a global reputation for speed, scale and efficiency. We are one of the world's leading providers of humanitarian aid in emergencies with recognized
technical expertise in clean water, public health, food security and the
protection of civilians. They couldn't do it without the vital funds from supporters like you.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. We achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
As a twisted solution to spending more time together, Laura has signed up the Junior Drew’s and long term suffering partners to Trail Walker 2018 - 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours.

We’ve had to bin the suggested training plan as quite frankly life must go on. Training has instead consisted of some very long walks (whilst grand parents get equally exhausted with the little people) and a far bit of running (with the smalls on bikes). And who knew - walking hurts!!!! We’ve had ankle injuries / allergic reactions / blisters on blisters / and a whole lot of hallucinations for cold drinks. We still have a lot of miles to clock up and still aren’t sure we can do it but we’d love your support. 

With donations for Oxfam down this year we’ve chosen to support them, so if you have any spare pennies and would like to give us a much needed boost, we’d love a donation! 

How about a pound for every toe nail lost 😂

title: I am Cycling to Paris with Kev and hoping to raise money for Oxfam.

Name: I am Cycling to Paris with Kev and hoping to raise money for Oxfam.

attribution: Our Team are Charlie, Nik, Patou and Jess
charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
All four of us wanted a challenge for 2018 and this will be a massive one. Trailwalker is described as the UK's toughest team challenge. We need to walk 100km of the South Downs Way in under 30 hours. That's more than 2 Marathons without sleep. It’s also in elevation terms the equivalent of climbing both Snowdonia and Ben Nevis together. Its going to be Hilarious!! 

All four of us are determined and if we can raise some money for both Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, so that they can help support some of the worlds poorest people, here in the UK and abroad, then those blisters will be very worthwhile.

For £14 Oxfam can provide shelter in a crisis

£20 can build a compost toilet in a community, helping to prevent the spread of disease.

£1 can provide drinking water for 10 people

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide pensions for veterans who aren’t entitled to a standard army pension, medical care and also community aid.

Anything you can give to these great causes, would be brilliant. Thanks so much

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
A team event, 4 people, 100km over 30 hours from 13-15 July 2018.  Bring it on!

We have all decided to take up this challenge to show our support for the amazing work that Oxfam carry out worldwide.

Being local to the Downs we have heard about this amazing event, and can't wait to try the Gurkha's infamous curry!

Please dig deep to support us, it's a non stop 30 hour challenge so every penny raised will motivate us through the difficult sections. We have a hard month of training ahead of us to make sure we are ready for the big day (and night), we can't wait to share our success with you 

Thanks in advance, thank you for your support and kind donations.


Tess, James, Catherine and Lucy

attribution: Radley Yeldar (RY) Team: Myself, Guy Jefferson, Greg Abramek and Maniyer Olson
charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you very much for visiting my Just-Giving page. On the
14th July it will be nearly 2 years to the day since my last Birmingham RY Team Challenge took place for Macmillan, completing 72 holes for golf in a day, which was both tiring and rewarding in equal measure… and here we are again – with possibly a far greater challenge… as at least with golf there are times to stop walking and play a shot!!

Our challenge this year is to participate as a team of 4 walkers and support team to complete the Trailwalk of 100km in 30 hours over the South Downs in supporting Oxfam – an amazing Charity. This promises to be a real test of our stamina and mental focus to keep going.

Having completed a training walk of 24 miles, taking 9 hours which is only just over a 1/3 of the final distance there is some apprehension …but let’s hope with the support of the team and wider organisers…along with energy drinks and chocolate… we make it to the finish within the 30 hours!)

I would be so grateful if you could support me to do this by making a donation for OXFAM. We shall keep you updated on our progress and thanks so much for your support.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I am taking part in the 2018 Trailwalker Challenge run by Oxfam
to raise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Gurkhas are a 200-year-old British Army Regiment, recruited predominantly from Japan. Gurkhas are known to be as fearless in combat as they are good natured in daily life.  Roughly 19,000 Gurkha soldiers have died during the many wars they have fought for this country. Many thousands more have been wounded, and more still have returned to a life of hardship in Nepal. The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides medical, financial and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and
their communities. More information can be found on the website
at https://www.gwt.org.uk

The Challenge was originally started by the Queen's Gurkha Signals Regiment over 30 years ago as a training exercise to test soldiers' stamina and teamwork skills.  The challenge is to complete the 100km Trailwalker trail across the South Downs in under 30 hours in a team of
4.   To put it another way, we'll be walking the distance of 2.3 marathons over terrain with the equivalent elevation of climbing Ben Nevis. Twice.

Any contribution you can make to this great charity is most
welcome.  Thanks for reading.

Ian

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hello family.

Thank you for visiting our page. On 13th - 15th July 2018 our team is taking part in the mammoth 100km Trailwalker. As a part of the event we have also pledged to raise £1400 in charity for Oxfam. 

Team has already raise  some money through charity auction . Now, each individual from team try to raise atleast £150 each.

It is more difficult to give money away intelligently than to earn it in the first place.

The money we raise will provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap.

We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give.

Thank you.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

"We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give."

Winston Churchill
----------------------------------------

Charity begins at home, but should not end there"

I am leading a team called, “1RGR Intake 2000” on an another gruesome adventure of completing 100km run (Trailwalker 2018), looking to raise money for Oxfam and GWT. The team consist of 4 members of 1RGR Intake 2000(joined the army at the same time) . 

It is not going to get any easier than last year, but looking at the team’s progress on the trainings so far, I am very confident that the team is well into completing the course (100km) within 15 hours time!

1RGR Intake 2000 is doing this to raise money to help the very needy people around the globe. The team will be supporting 2 charity organisations; Gurkha Welfare Trust which ensures that Gurkha veterans, their widows and their wider communities are able to live with dignity. They achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical and community aid in Nepal. The another one is Oxfam.I request all my friends, colleagues and relatives to search for humanity into your soul and donate whatever amount you can for this very worthy cause. Every penny you will donate will make a difference to someone’s life somewhere around the world. We, together, can make the world better! Please help me raise money. for these charitable organisations. You can click at the link above or below to donate. Many thank you all.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Team Green was formed by a group of runners in 1990s Hong Kong. The team has participated in Oxfam's Trailwalker event there every year since and traditionally turn out strong teams of dedicated and passionate ultra marathon runners. The UK Trailwalker takes entrants 100km along the full length of the South Downs Way from Petersfield in southern England over rolling hills and through sleepy villages to its end at Brighton Racecourse.

Tilly, Tanya, David and Paul come from very different backgrounds, brought together through their love of running and racing ultra distances. This challenge is as difficult as any with the team element meaning even small setbacks affect all members of the team. The close bond enjoyed by Team Green will help with this and through plenty of determination, resilience and light hearted banter we expect to enjoy our journey together.

We hope you will consider sponsoring us with whatever you can afford to help towards defeating worldwide poverty.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In need of a challenge and to raise money for 2 great causes, my husband - Rich - 2 friends - Graham and Matt - and I are taking on Trailwalker 2018. We are hiking 100km of the South Downs Way, from Queen Elizabeth Country Park to Brighton Race Course, on 13th-14th July. We have been given 30 hours in which to do this and we are aiming for 24! From the training that we have done so far, we know this is going to be painful--particularly at 4am!

We are raising money for both Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, both of whom do valuable world around the world. If you are able to donate, whatever the amount, we would all be incredibly grateful,

With thanks,

Beth

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I will be taking on the UK's number one team endurance challenge -Trial Walker again (don't ask why) - where we try to complete 100 k in under 20 hours #teamdalbhatpower basically meaning rice lentel power -(yes it's actually our team name 😂) each of us have to raise £350 each and total of £1400 for the oxfam. All the money raised will support both the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust. Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world and the Gurkha trust for almost 50 years has provided welfare to enable these Gurkha veterans, their dependants and their communities to live their lives with dignity. The core of the Trust's work has always been the Welfare Pension. Your donation even if it's £1 will greatly help these charities with their noble cause. 

Thank you for your time and interest


Regards


Prashant

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi, thanks for taking the time to visit my Trailwalker 2018 fundraising page.

The girls and I are undertaking the Trailwalker 2018 challenge, walking 100 kilometres (approximately 62 miles) along the South Downs Way in under 30 hours on 14-15 July 2018. Our fabulous support crew will meet us at 9 checkpoints to provide replenishments (edible or otherwise) and much needed encouragement and support! Other than these 15-20 minute breaks at each checkpoint, the only rest we will be getting will be at the end of the challenge, 30 hours later. Stupid amounts of sleep deprivation, aching feet, complete and utter exhaustion, and hopefully a MASSIVE sense of achievement - here we come!

One of the great things about this challenge is that donations go to the wonderful Gurkha Welfare Trust (https://www.gwt.org.uk/) and Oxfam, so do please help us help the Gurkhas, one step at a time.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
After a "once in a lifetime" challenge in 2015 it appears that this event has got hold of me!

It is a brutal, amazing, exhausting, exhilarating, painful experience but one that is worth it for the money we can raise for two really great charities (Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam).

After the monsoon that was 2017 we are back to get under the 24hr time for the event.  It is going to make the challenge even tougher but I think we have the right team of walkers and support crew to get this done!

We are sadly only a team of 3 this year which makes everything a little bit tougher from the fundraising to the walk itself but I`m still confident we can hit our goals.

If you would like to donate any amount towards us doing this event for such great causes then I would be very grateful.  All the money raised goes to the charities as the entrance fee we have already paid covers the costs of running the event.

Thank you for reading and if you would prefer to donate with a different method then just get in touch!

thanks!!

Matt

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Al Hearn, Luke Breward, Dan Bradbury and Tom Holt make up The Four Must-Get-Heres...

Where must we get? 100km across the South Downs from Petersfield to Brighton. This is not your average sponsored silence or cake-eating competition - there will be blisters and chafing - so dig deep and throw us a few quid. 

We're doing this to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, which is a great cause.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha community.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

When I was asked if I would like to join a team to take on the Trailwalker challenge, I immediately said "yes!". After all, it's just a walk, how hard can it be!? After a couple of 40k training walks I've decided the answer is.....very hard. This is no walk in the park! Ok yes it is in a National Park but that's beside the point. 

The walk will see myself, along with my friends Richard and Beth Maynard and Matteo Bunce, start at Queen Elizabeth country park and finish (hopefully) at Brighton racecourse. A walk off 100k! We have 30 hours to complete it although we hope to finish in under 24. 

Our fundraising is on behalf of both Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, two organisations who do amazing work around the world. If you are able to donate, whatever the amount, we would all be extremely grateful. 

To find out more about the event, visit https://www.oxfam.org.uk/trailwalker. 

Thanks for all of us,

Graham

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our page. We will be walking 100 km within 30 hrs time from Queen Elizabeth Country park to Brighton Racecourse for the weekend of 14th & 15th July. 

We are Team YATTRI - Jyoti-teamleader, Myself, Divya and Sahash and Ashish (who is our backup who is doing equal amount of practise) and our Support Crew-  self proclaimed managers (Dil Aunty, Yem Uncle, Savi my dear hubby and Dipen. :)

There will be thousands of trailwalkers & volunteers alongside us, walking through the South Downs trail in order to Raise Money To End Poverty Around The World. The money we raise will support both the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust which is very close to my heart coming from a Gurkha background myself.

Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event and we will require as much support as possible. We need to raise atleast £1000 in order to QUALIFY  for the event and although you may want to be physically there to witness our first Trailwalker success, just few minutes of your time in going through our page and donating will mean the world to us. 

Thank you and wish us luck !

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi. 

So as you're here then you might know that me along with three friends have signed up to do Trialwalker 2018. Trailwalker is an endurance event that not only will have me traveling 100k (62miles) across the south downs but over the course of that 100k we will ascend 2500m. The equivalent of climbing Ben Nevis and mount Snowden. The event organizers set a 30 hour time limit with the average finish time from previous years being 27 hours. Yes that means that other that stops for food a toilet breaks I will be continually walking. Even through the night.

You might say I'm crazy and you are right but hardships are a part of life. Unfortunately some people in the world experience hardships we can never imagine. I feel it's the obligation of those that can, to help those who are in need. I want to challenge myself, to help I others, and to decrease suffering. With your help, that is exactly what I hope we will do together.

Thank you

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
THIS EVENT WAS CANCELLED DUE TO ADVERSE WEATHER.


On 13-15 July 2018, Team Wilcox, made up of Louis, Malcolm and Lili (with invaluable support from our amazing support crew) will hike 100km over the South Downs in South East England.  

We'll head off at 7.30am on Saturday 14th July and just keep on running, jogging, walking, crawling, until we've covered the 100km - through sunshine (we hope), rain (more likely), and darkness (guaranteed).  We need to complete the trek in 30 hours or less. Last year the team managed 50km before two of the group pulled out through injury.

We will be training in the lead-up to the event, and also trying to raise money.  Our minimum fundraising target is £1400.  If we raise this much this money will provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children from waterborne diseases.

Team Wilcox would be very grateful for your donation.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

A Big Thank You from me and the team for donating. xx

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Here is the background to what we're doing. Please support it if you can.  Exercise TRAILWALKER started out as a military training exercise in Hong Kong in 1981. Organised by the Queen's Gurkha Signals, and taking place along the famous Maclehose Trail, the exercise sought to test the endurance and teamwork of soldiers of the Queen's Gurkha Signals over a long and arduous course.

In 1986, Trailwalker was opened to civilian participation for the first time, and now, 30 years later, following the move of the Queen's Gurkha Signals to the UK, the 100k event takes place across the South Downs, with hundreds of civilians setting off from the start line alongside the Gurkhas.

Over the years of charitable partnership, the exercise has raised significant funds for Oxfam GB and the GWT, making a real difference to the lives of families and people around the world. Most recently, money raised from the Gurkha 200 edition of Ex TRAILWALKER was instrumental in reconstruction and relief in the wake of the tragic earthquakes in Nepal.

Since the return of the Brigade of Gurkhas to the United Kingdom in 1997, the Queen's Gurkha Signals sought to continue the tradition of Exercise TRAILWALKER. With the first event being held in 1998, the course was set across the South Downs National Park in Sussex. The traditional character of the exercise was preserved as closely as possible.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Many of my recent travels have taken place on foot, and although I won't be carrying the usual heavy pack, I have never faced such a long distance over such a short period of time before.  I don't usually take up physical challenges like this, but I have recently started rowing and I am very pleased that the team spirit created through sitting in a boat on the river with a bunch of other crazies, often at unmentionable hours in the morning, has brought this opportunity.  My walking is usually for my own work and enjoyment; it seems a very fitting way to raise money for Oxfam where, for many of the folk Oxfam works to support, that enjoyment is driven out by necessity. 

A huge thank you to all of you who are supporting me and my team on this walk and the work of Oxfam.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The Gurkhas were recruited into and been part of the British Army for the last 200 years.

Roughly 19,000 Gurkha soldiers have died during the many wars they've fought at Britain's side, and more still have returned to a life of hardship in Nepal.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust ensures that Gurkha veterans, their widows and their wider communities are able to live with dignity.

They achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical and community aid in Nepal and offer advice and support to help the thousands of retired Gurkhas and their families who choose to settle here.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As you may have already heard, I am taking part in the 2018 Trailwalker Challenge run by Oxfam and the expertise of the Gurkha Welfare Trust. If you're not familiar with either, here is a little background story.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty for everyone.

They take on the big issues that keep people poor - like inequality, hunger and climate change. Bringing hope in disaster, changing lives with water aid and helping to protect from disease.

The Gurkhas are soldiers from Nepal who are recruited into the British Army, and have been for the last 200 years. Gurkhas are known to be as fearless in combat as they are good natured in daily life.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides medical, financial and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and their communities. More information can be found on the website at https://www.gwt.org.uk

The challenge itself is taking place on a 100km route across the South Downs from 13-15 July with a team of 4 of us aiming to finish this monster walk! It's quite easy to underestimate what walking 100km (62 miles) entails. Having just completed our first grueling 30 mile training walk, further than any of us had ever walked, I can tell you that it's a lot of blisters, sore knees and stiff hips. Add in to the mix the element of sleep deprivation from walking right through the night and the fact that we'll have to do double the distance of our longest walk so far, you start to see that this will be no walk in the park. To put it another way, we'll be walking the distance of 2.3 marathons over terrain with the equivalent elevation of climbing Ben Nevis twice!

Any contribution you can make to this great charity is most welcomed, thanks for reading.

Mark

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

https://youtu.be/nAL6h8QxDYE

Participants in Trailwalker UK jointly fundraise for both Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. 

The Gurkha Welfare Trust was founded in 1969, when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age. Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in the Second World War and other conflicts; however they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an army pension.

For almost 50 years the Trust has provided welfare to enable these Gurkha veterans, their dependants and their communities to live their lives with dignity. The core of the Trust's work has always been the Welfare Pension, which is currently distributed to over 5,500 brave Gurkha veterans and widows.

Outside of this financial aid, the Trust also offers comprehensive medical and community programmes across Nepal.

story:
On 13-15 July 2018, Team Wilcox, made up of Louis, Leila, Malcolm and Lili (with invaluable support from our amazing support crew) will hike 100km over the South Downs in South East England.  

We'll head off at 7am on Saturday 14th July and just keep on running, jogging, walking, crawling, until we've covered the 100km - through sunshine (we hope), rain (more likely), and darkness (guaranteed).  We need to complete the trek in 30 hours or less. Last year the team managed 50km before two of the group pulled out through injury.

We will be training in the lead-up to the event, and also trying to raise money.  Our minimum fundraising target is £1400.  If we raise this much this money will provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children from waterborne diseases.

Team Wilcox would be very grateful for your donation.

Thank you for taking the time to visit my page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Well, that is the core reason for oxfam to organise such a big event every year, however there should always be more than one reason to do something or to not do that same thing.

I have mine which are a little bit more than words, they are more like feelings, feelings of seeing and knowing  kids of my age living across the road who didn't have proper homes to live in, proper clothes to wear, they didn't go to school like I did, they weren't allowed to come in the same court yard as us, yet we were able to see them and feel them gazing at us with our fancy clothes, toys and food. 

If you know me at all you would know how many questions I can ask, so as a young child I still remember I used to always ask my grand-mother, my mother why are those kids the way they are, why can't they just cross over and play with us and we can share our toys and be happy but I was told they are "poor". (Please  I do not mean to be controversial here, I could write an other article on how my parents & family are doing their part to make a difference but that is not the point!)

However, I didn't really understand what was meant by "poor" but today I do and I know for sure that poverty is not a choice, there is not just one cause of poverty, and the results of it are different in every case. Poverty varies considerably depending on the situation. Feeling poor in Canada is different from living in poverty in Pakistan, Zimbabwe or Russia.  The differences between rich and poor within the borders of a country also great, I have seen it through my eyes and felt it in my bones.

With poverty comes many other societal issues such as mental health, physical illnesses depression and many more. So today for the first time I officially create a fund raising page (otherwise I am always doing crazy stuff for charities Bungee jumping, next on list is Sky Diving!) however this time its a for a cause that we all need to take some sort of responsibility towards and come together as human race to tackle one of worst violence people just like me and you face on daily basis. 

Also - I don't really care if you pay even one pence towards my cause that is more than enough but leave your name so I can personally Thank You. I will even consider your positive thoughts as part of this journey and charity.

Loads of Love 

Sadia Kazmi

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We are friends who work in the Haematology and Blood Transfusion lab at St Richards Hospital in Chichester.

We wanted to take on a challenge and raise some money for charity at the same time..

We are blessed to live in a beautiful part of the country and with the South Downs on our doorstep we decided to sign up to the Trailwalker challenge.


Trailwalker raises money for 2 worthwhile charities, Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.


The Gurkha Welfare Trust was founded in 1969, when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age. Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in the Second World War and other conflicts; however they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an army pension.

For almost 50 years the Trust has provided welfare to enable these Gurkha veterans, their dependants and their communities to live their lives with dignity. The core of the Trust's work has always been the Welfare Pension, which is currently distributed to over 5,500 brave Gurkha veterans and widows.

Outside of this financial aid, the Trust also offers comprehensive medical and community programmes across Nepal.

Any support you could give us would be much appreciated and we will keep you updated with our training progress.

Thank you.

Zoe, Carol & Ola xxx

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Trailwalker really is a remarkable event which will raise money for the Gurkha Welfare trust. 

The Gurkhas are soldiers from Nepal who are recruited into the British Army, and have been for the last 200 years. Gurkhas are known to be as fearless in combat as they are good natured in daily life... they are really superhuman in many ways. As an example, most recently they helped rebuild villages in Nepal after the 2015 earthquake. They will be RUNNING this 100km walk, putting our efforts to shame when we (hopefully) stumble over the finish line. 

SO our challenge: we have to walk 100km pretty much without stopping over a period of 24hours.. with no sleep and very little breaks. Anything will help make this all worthwhile!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The Challenge

On 13th – 15th July 2018, will be walking 100km along the South Downs Way from Petersfield to Brighton in Under 30 hours. This ultimate test of endurance will be furthest any of us have ever walked in one go before. Plus, the route takes on the equivalent of climbing both Snowden and Ben Nevis, so it’s going to be pretty tough!

The Team

Team Ghurkin is made up of Oscar, Ben, Sophie & Sam and will be supported by The Selcons, HD, JD, CB and HB!

Oscar – Flora and fauna expert, if there is an interesting bird or rare flower on the walk, he will be sure to spot it.

Ben – Geography teacher & official map reader – so we’ll probably get lost.

Sophie – Official snack monitor and team bossy boots.

Sam – Mr Motivator – when energy is low and we’re all flagging, Silky Sam can always be relied upon to perk us up and boost morale.

The Money

Every penny we raise will be used by Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust to help improve lives around the world.


The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years we've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection.

Any donations big or small will be greatly appreciated. With your help, support and encouragement...we might just make it!

Remember: Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never share them with anyone or send you unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. They'll make sure Gift Aid (an additional 25%) is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer, too. That means more money goes to the charity, faster, with JustGiving.

CHARITY CHALLENGE EVENT: TRAILWALKER 14/15 JULY 2018

The Gurkha/Oxfam Trailwalker challenge starts from Queen Elizabeth Country Park near Petersfield, Hampshire. The challenge is for teams of four to cover 100km (62.5 miles) of the South Downs in the fastest time possible and within the 30-hour maximum time limit. The whole team must cover the entire distance  together from start to finish.  It’s the equivalent of completing almost two-and-a-half marathons and climbing Ben Nevis in one session without any rest.

I am participating for the 20th time in team "Truly Over the Hill" to raise funds for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and OXFAM. Once again I am joined by Legend Trailwalker  Julian Maicheal, fast paceman Jones Aygeman and this year it is a privilege to welcome my grandson Aidan Sanders who is keen to undertake this formidable challenge. Thanks to your generosity my teams have raised around £30,000 for these very worthy causes. 

 Following the two devastating Nepal earthquakes in 2015 funds are desperately needed to continue rebuilding homes and schools.

Your support over so many years has been inspiring and The Gurkha Welfare Trust and OXFAM are deeply grateful. Thank you for your enduring support.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Since spring 2017 a staggering 18.8 million - 70 per cent of Yemen's  population - are suffering from food insecurity and acute malnutrition.  

The famine is being compounded by Yemen facing the world’s worst ever recorded cholera outbreak, which has spread across the war-ravaged country.  More than 1 million cases have been reported and over 2,200 people have died since the start of the epidemic.

I am working with Oxfam GB as their Young Ambassador to help raise money for delivering aid for the people in Yemen. Between July 23rd - 25th 2018, I will be participating in a '40 hour famine' - no food for 40 hours. 

I kindly ask all who are willing to support me to donate what you can. Millions of Yemenis are in desperate need of help, but your donations can help bring food and water to families in crisis. 

Thank you!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The official reason for this walk as you can imagine is to help end poverty. It is organised with the Queen's Gurkha Signals and Oxfam. 

My reason, well a lot more than i can put in to words. It obviously first started as a joke, and now i am here committed to this more than anything.  It has become more personal than official. I would love to meet the target for my fundraising, but if I didn't, I'd still be happy in wanting take  part, I'd still be happy that I went on a hike every weekend without a fail, I'd still be happy that I crossed a mental barrier for myself and I broke my own limitation. 

However, knowing that I will be able to help the poor by doing this extreme challenge it only makes me happier and push myself above and beyond my limitation. It has given me the ambitious to always remember the poor and help in ways that I didn't know off. 

I hope everyone finds a reason to help someone and if not by walking then maybe by supporting my cause, because we cant help everyone but everyone can help someone.

story:
The mission, which we have chosen to accept, is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours. That's more than two Marathons, back-to-back. We blame clever marketing for our acceptance of this challenge - that and our good friend for convincing us this would be a good idea, before pulling out and wishing us 'good luck!'

All joking aside, we are super excited to be taking part in this incredible event for such a worthy cause. From women's rights to water; emergency relief to education; Oxfam's work is making a real difference to the lives of people in poverty. But they need our support to reach more people. By donating today, you can bring hope to people across the globe and create a better future for generations to come.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Having met on university netball courts back in 2007, our main successes were our carefully curated matching outfits for sports night. 

In later years our group sporting activities have included the occasional group stroll around Dartmouth. And, after the last Devon outing, we haphazardly and over-enthusiastically thought we might be able to endure walking 100k in 30 hours. We can be sure our conversation won't run out, let's just hope on legs don't either.

You're generous financial support will be sure to push us on and help raise vital funds for Oxfam.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
***Event cancelled***

Please bare with us whilst we work out a plan. We have a possible alternative 100km event in September.


The team Wilkos Wanderers consists of supreme team leader Matthew Wilkinson and plebs Harry Munro, Lewis McLean, Fred Schwartz and Ian Dickson. In July we will take on a 100km hilly run/walk along the South Downs from just north of Portsmouth to the far side of Brighton  (2 marathons + 10miles) known as the Trailwalker. It’s organised by the Queens Gurkha regiment and they also hold the course record at sub 10 hours! With over 2000 people competing in teams of 4 or 5, including a lot of military teams, our chances of winning are admittedly slim but just finishing within the 30 hour time limit would be a great achievement as the dropout rate is over 50%!. 

Thank you for your donation it’s much appreciated and makes it all worthwhile, it will help keep us going when we are walking through the night, feet covered in blisters, sunburnt and low on vaseline. Finally we are assured by Oxfam that your donation won’t be spent by staff on “extra curricular” activities.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Dear all,


I and Ladies of 1 RGR formed up a Ladies team to take part in Trail walker 2018.  Trailwalker is an ultimate endurance challenge of 100 km charity walk, being held in the surroundings of South Downs Way of Wales, within 30 hours in a team of four.  Although Trailwalker is kind of men-only event raising donation for Oxfam and GWT,  I and my Team decided to come out of our comfort zone to take part in this ultimate challenge representing 1 RGR Ladies to raise money for the GWT in support of the needy Gurkha veterans in Nepal.

My Team and I are very keen and determined not only to take part in this challenge, but also to raise £500/- through this arduous charity walk for the GWT in support of needy Gurkha veteran, their families and communities in Nepal by reflecting our ability to do things well out of the comfort zone.

The team, therefore, appeal for your generous support by sponsoring our team to help us to raise said amount for this worthy cause.  Your little contribution will make a huge difference to needy Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal.  Please sponsor our team by donating any size of amount you can by tapping on JustGiving.com on our page.

Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page and for your generosity.
