charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Most (all) good stories start in the pub, and after a pint with some mates we made a very naive decision - "Let's do Trailwalker, it can't be that bad!".  At the time it seemed clever, but as the event approaches we are becoming less certain...

The 100km course stretches from Winchester to Brighton along the South Downs Way with a combined ascent of 2500m (Ben Nevis + Snowdon) and must be completed as a group of four in as quick a time as possible.

So please help encourage us by dipping your hands into your wallets for two exceedingly worthy causes.  The Gurkha Welfare Trust is particularly close to my heart as I prepare to join 1st Battalion, The Royal Gurkha Rifles as they train for operations. 

The Trust ensures that Gurkha veterans, their widows and their wider communities are able to live their lives with dignity. This is primarily achieved through the provision of financial, medical and community aid distributed through numerous busy Area Welfare Centres throughout Nepal.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks
for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The mission, which we have chosen to accept, is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours. That's more than two Marathons,
back-to-back. We blame clever marketing for our acceptance of this challenge -that and our good friend for convincing us this would be a good idea, before
pulling out and wishing us 'good luck!'

All joking aside, we are very excited to be taking part in this incredible event for such a worthy cause. From women's rights to water; emergency relief to education; Oxfam's work is making a real difference to the lives of people in poverty. But they need our support to reach more people. By donating today, you
can bring hope to people across the globe and create a better future for generations to come.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you
donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you so much in advance for your support - we'll certainly need it!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

On 14th July 2018, Rachel Mussett, Hannah May, Sally McCleery & Iain Jackson were due to walk 100km of the South Downs to raise money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust, however due to the incredibly hot weather the event had to be cancelled.

We have decided to roll over our entry fee to 2019, and have also contacted our sponsors to see if they are happy for their donations to be rolled over. Most have said yes, and so we will have a bit less work to do next year!

In Summer 2019 we'll be walking for approximately 30 hours with no sleep, powered by flapjack and good will.

Check out this video which shows a bit more of what we're going to be doing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8oHA2x45Dg#action=share

Please help us to raise money for these two wonderful causes! Your donation will go toward the 2019 event.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page and we really appreciate any donation you may make

As you can imagine Trailwalker is a very tough challenge and we have set ourselves a target of 24 hours to complete it. We will set off at 10AM Saturday 14 July and walk/jog continuously until 10AM Sunday with eight 20 minute stops. Last year the weather was atrocious and we are hoping it's not the case this year!

We are all runners with different levels of experience and we will cross the finish line together (we have to!). BTW the Ghurkhas use this course for their training and they complete it in under 9 hours! We have been training for the last four months with our first walk in thick snow. Our last session will be 40 miles over two days walking on the Trailwalker course, this helps us to familiarise ourselves with the terrain

Sue, Angela, Graham and myself will be attempting the challenge and we will be met at each checkpoint  by our Support Vehicle and Crew, David (Apples) and Bob (The Mechanic)

Established in 1969, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. We achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid

Thanks for your support!



Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

ご覧いただき、有難うございます。

我々はオックスファム・トレイルウォーカーに参加します。

このイベントは４人1組のチームで参加する世界的に行われているウォーキング・イベントです。自分の体力に挑戦すると同時に、参加をきっかけに寄付金を集めて国際協力に貢献するというもうひとつの挑戦が用意された企画で、これまでに香港、オーストラリア、ニュージーランド、イギリス、オランダ、カナダ、ベルギー、アイルランドで開催され、日本でも2007年から毎年開催されています。


オックスファム・トレイルウォーカーへのご寄付は、

国際協力団体オックスファムの実施する途上国の紛争・災害時の緊急支援、教育・農業支援などの国際協力活動に使われ、人々が貧困から立ち上がるために役立てられています。特に2015年は東北復興支援として開催地を福島となっています。

皆さんのご理解、ご協力をお願い致します。

We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
So, four grown men, sorry, four grown middle aged men, decide we can take on the Gurkha Challenge of walking 100km in 30hours over the South Downs, now when we decided that this was doable to say not all of us are as physically fit and we once were is an understatement.  Some of us aren't going to be much fitter come the start of the challenge, but that's all part of the fun.  More importantly, by us doing this we are helping raise money for a fantastic cause, the Oxfam Poverty Appeal is a great cause so please give generously!

We will continue to avoid any form of training and rock up on the day expecting to break the course record, in reality, we will be the ones that are broken, but we will finish... that much I guarantee you!
title: Team Underprepared
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Team Underprepared

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I can’t actually remember when I officially signed up to this nonsense. Ha

100 kilometres is a distance I would possibly refuse to drive on the grounds that it’s too far!

It is a bit ridiculous!

However on the premise that it is helping some misfortunate souls somewhere in our world then i suppose it’s a good cause for some self torture.

I also look forward to seeing some dear friends of mine slowly deteriorating both physically and mentally until they are broken men, cognitively impaired shadows of their former selfs. Then watching them having to deal with the carnival wackiness encountered at the various checkpoints. I think the tambourines and foghorns could be the tipping point to complete psychosis for some of my team members whichI look forward to witnessing very much.


I do sincerely hope that your generous donations make their way to it’s charitable cause, however I cannot guarantee that it won’t be just funding the party / local prostitute kitty for deployed Oxfam employees : sorry Oxfam we haven’t forgotten!

Warm regards

Ben

story:
Thanks for visiting our Just Giving site - the simplest way to contribute to Team GR8 Britain.

Oxfam Trailwalker is a challenging endurance fundraising event in which Akira, David, Lucy and Chris from the British Embassy, Tokyo will complete a 100km trail through bush terrain in 48 hours. We will be starting at Odawara and heading to Yamanaka-ko, one of Mt Fuji's five lakes. The walk will be completed between 16-18 May 2014.

Money raised will be used to support Oxfam’s programmes around the world - any donation amount is appreciated.

Thanks!

Team GR8 Britain

story:
We are going to challenge Oxfam Trail Walker 2014 in Japan which is part of an international series, with an incredible 17 events being held around the world in 11 countries.

Our team will walk 100 kilometers in 48 hours - in all weather and across some rough terrain. We will work together to all complete the distance within the time.

As part of this challenge, we are raising funds for Oxfam's life-saving work thorough this event and your donation would be greatly appreciated.

Your donation will be used to fund Oxfam's emergency work worldwide.

Thank you!

Team Information;

No.091 Cairn Terrier

Yoichi Higashihara

Yuri Hatakeyama

Marina Haniu

Mai Hasegawa

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Sightsavers is 1 of my 2 chosen charities - it is an charity that works in developing countries to prevent blindness and restore sight by treating eye conditions such as cataracts, trachoma, refractive error and eye conditions caused by tropical diseases.  Your donation really can make a difference;

  • £4 could pay for a cataract operation to save a child going blind
  • £8 could pay for trachoma operations to stop 12 people going blind.
  • £12 could pay for treatment to prevent 2,184 people losing their sight to river blindness.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am raising money for Sightsavers because having recently had a cataract removed myself in the comfort of a UK hospital I want to raise awareness that there are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80 per cent of blindness could be prevented or cured.

That’s 31.2 million people who are blind when it could have been avoided. Sightsavers want to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind or disabled to live independently.

Martin

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder but what if the beholder didn't have sight!?

Without eyesight I can only imagine how someone would feel... Angry, Devastated, Afraid, Frustrated, Isolated, Alone, Different, Lost, Confused.... These are just a few of the many emotions blind people and their parents feel when their child is diagnosed with a lifelong eye condition.

The beauty of this world is felt by the heart but seen by eyes. I believe no-one should be denied this independence, this basic human sense or jewel of the body, if something can be done to rectify it.

“There are only two ways to live your life. One is as though nothing is a miracle. The other is as though everything is a miracle” and I believe that every dream can come true with hard work and determination. My name is Sehrish Zafar and I am an entertainment journalist and a TV Presenter. I understand it is not easy to encourage people to think optimistically, so that's where my charismatic personality and charm can help inspire people to make a difference in the society.

I am currently a freelance TV Presenter for various UK asian channels; I host at many stage events: fashion, charity, political and award ceremonies especially within our community. I am a graduate of BA Business Management and an award holder of 'Miss Perfect' at college.

Other achievements include fundraising for charities like Save the Children, Ucare Foundation; working as an Events Director of Pakistan Youth Foundation - Organised dinner events for Pakistani politicians, protests against Burma and Gaza Killings, promoted local community cultural music events, visited House of Commons and Pakistan High Commission on many occasions to support our community.

As I have selflessly helped support the dreams of others and those of my community, I hope I will continue to receive the help and support I seek to fundraise for those in need the most. I am fasting in aid of Sightsavers and your generous support in this great cause will aid me to do more for the ones who need the help most. 

 

Sightsavers believes that no one should be blind from avoidable causes, and that people’s whose sight can’t be saved should live with dignity and independence.

 

Did you know?

There are 39 million blind people in the world

80% of blindness can be prevented or cured

Around 90% of visually impaired people live in the world’s poorest countries

So the problems Sightsavers are trying to tackle are pretty enormous.

 

So please dig deep and donate now.

 

Thank you,

Sehrish

So it’s the most efficient way to donate - I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Hiii,

Those who know me already know my story for those who don't here it is....

I was diagnosed with right homonymous hemianopia. This is a visual field loss on the same side of both eyes. In my case it was caused by a stroke.

Although my sight cannot be regained there are people in 3rd world countries who are struggling with sight loss daily due to dirty water and surroundings.

We can actually help them!. 

All I ask is for people to donate as little as £2 to help save someone's sight.  

£12 - could protect 35 families from river blindness a year!

 £28 - Could pay for a  cataract operation and give someone their sight back! 

£140 - Could treat and protect an entire village from trachoma! 

Just a few examples of what your money could be doing.

Sightsavers Currently works in the following counties:

Bangladesh, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Chad, Côte d’Ivoire, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, India, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Nigeria, Pakistan, Republic of Congo, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania, The Gambia, Togo, Uganda, Yemen, Zambia and Zimbabwe


Thank you in advance for anyone that donates it means more than words can express.

charity.name: Sightsavers
eventName: Our Aotearoa Adventure: a long bike ride on the other side of the world.
story:
Earlier this year I had emergency eye surgery for a detached retina.  Thanks to the swift response and expertise of the eye unit where I was treated I have regained the sight in my right eye.  I'm still having problems with cataracts in my left eye but I know this will be sorted in due course with a relatively quick and easy operation.  The experience of temporary sight loss  made me appreciate how lucky I am to live in a country where we have access to free health care via the NHS.  Thousands of people in developing countries don't have this privilege and as a result cataracts or a detached retina can lead to permanent blindness resulting in a loss of independence, income and an inability to care for their families.  In the case of children these conditions can have a devastating impact on their future.  These and other eye conditions are easily preventable and treatable with access to funding and the expertise that we take for granted in the UK.  By donating to Sightsavers  you are helping the charity to work in some of the world's poorest areas to prevent and treat eye conditions that would otherwise lead to permanent blindness.

All donations will go to the charity.  We are totally self funding the trip.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

80 per cent of all blindness could be prevented or cured. It is a staggering statistic: that’s over 31 million people, most of whom live in the poorest countries in the world. And with poverty being both a cause and effect of blindness, a cycle is created that can be hard for communities to break out of.

Sightsavers wants to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. They help blind people to see, prevent others from going blind unnecessarily, and support people to live independently if their sight loss can’t be undone.

The causes of avoidable blindness go further than eye disease, so Sightsavers doesn’t just slap a sticking-plaster on the problem – they campaign to make a fairer world and change lives for the long term, helping to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. Help us to support Sightsavers in this incredible cause.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Sightsavers work to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote the rights of people with disabilities. Sightsavers are trying to eliminate trachoma, the world’s leading infectious cause of blindness: 

https://www.sightsavers.org/protecting-sight/ntds/what-is-trachoma/

TED-of-the-day talk:

https://www.sightsavers.org/news/2018/06/ted-of-the-day/

In short, trachoma starts off as a bacterial infection that’s a bit like conjunctivitis and can be easily treated. However, if left untreated it causes scarring to the eyelid that makes the eyelashes turn inward, and with every blink they scrape against the eye. This causes intense pain, and over time, blindness.

Trachoma has been eliminated in many parts of the world, so the plan is to wipe it out in the 43 countries that still count trachoma as a public health problem.

To raise money to fight trachoma, I am going to try and run non-stop for 24 hours at the Cotswold 24 hour race:

https://www.100milerun.com/cotswold-24-hour-race/

Any distance over 52 miles will be a new personal best for me, but my goal is to run 100 miles or more. It's going to hurt, but if I hit my donation target it will be worth the pain. In June 2018, Ghana made history as the first country in sub-Saharan Africa and the Commonwealth to eliminate trachoma, so the campaign has already had great success.  

£8.00 pays for trachoma operations to stop two people going blind. Any donation, large or small, will help to end trachoma for good.

Many thanks,

Matthew

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
On 1st June 2018 I will be setting off with my daughter, Olivia, to cycle from home, near Bristol, to Land's End and back - a distance of around 475 miles over 8 days. I am 61, Olivia is 22. 

In September last year I suffered a torn retina, which was repaired by wonderful staff at Bristol Eye Hospital. It gave me an insight into the devastating effect loss of vision can have on ones life. 

In January last year, whilst visiting a village on the Mekong River in Laos, I saw a young boy who had a vision defect that resulted in him being excluded by his fellow peers and destined to a life of poverty.  A simple operation would remedy that defect and allow him to lead a full and active life as he grows up in his village. 

Sight Savers delivers that treatment to those like him and thousands of others.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Friends,

I'm training for a half marathon in my home city of Glasgow on September 30th, but to spice it up this year I've decided to try and raise some sponsorship...

This past year I travelled the world again for work, and saw the harsh conditions that some people live with, especially on the African continent. I visited a school for the blind, and saw how hard it is to live in some places, to get an education and to feed your family, if you're visually impaired. So once again (it's been a few years), with your generous help,  I'd like raise what ever money I can for a charity I care about - Sightsavers International. 

As a photographer who relies on their own sight and vision, this charity is obviously dear to me, and I'd like to help them in their work. Sightsavers work to combat preventable blindness in developing countries, restoring sight through specialist treatment and eye care. They also support people who are irreversibly blind by providing education, counselling and training. They help the people who need it most - those living in poverty in some of the world's poorest countries. Even small donations can have a huge impact on someone's life,  £8 funds a sightsaving trachoma operation, £28 provides treatment to prevent a community losing their sight to river blindness, £50 can fund a cataract operation to give a child back their sight.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate - I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I appreciate times are tough for a lot of us, but please think how tough it'd be if you live in the developing world and can't see, and can't work to feed your family. So please dig deep if you can and donate now. Every contribution helps - the price of a cappucino, a pint of beer - it can mean the difference between someone seeing or not seeing.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. And the target of £1,310? - There's 13.1 miles in a half marathon. Your generosity will help me get through the training and run the course. 

Speak soon,

Jeremy

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page

As we are getting married in South Africa my (Alex's) grandparents were unable to attend. Nan and grandad have been second parents to us growing up and their house was always filled with happiness and kindness. They first met when they were 14, continued to live a happy loving life at 88 and are an inspiration to us on our wedding day. It is important to us that they are a part of our day and so we asked them to pick a charity that meant something to them. Grandad picked Sightsavers straight away. He couldn't believe, that for so little money, children all over the world could have their vision returned and yet so many were still left blind and vulnerable. He had already donated to this cause himself.

13 days after grandad picked this charity for us, on 13th July 2018, he passed away surrounded by many people that loved him. Grandad's life was lived with love, kindness and generosity and it seems fitting that we should be remembering him by giving to a cause that meant a lot to him. Please give generously for us in his honour.

Grandad you will be missed but it's hard to be too sad when someone lived such a great life and touched so many people.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thank you to all who supported the Cake and Samosa sale, we did amazing!!! Together, your efforts will transform so many lives. Each one of you is truly awesome and I have been blown away by your generosity, not just with donations but with the time you have dedicated and support :D

We are organising and hoping to cycle from London to Paris to try raise awareness and funds for sightsavers. Most of us are lucky enough to conceive/see, so we are able to carry out basic tasks and live independently. We can dream, empower and be included, but unfortunately some members of our human family are struck by preventable blindness which leaves them detached and in most instances trapped in inconceivable poverty. Mobility not just physical but social and economical is lost to blindness. 

We are therefore hoping that we can in someway help lift this veil of blindness so on a practical level, we can help make people more independent physically and this will filter through to all aspects of their life.

Our only motivation is Hope - that our actions and contributions can help and will make a difference.  Small steps may lead to others to  see rainbows, the raw world in all it's vividness. So, we hope, restoring vision will  provide opportunity to others to experience all that we do on a daily basis. Have the same chance. Just like when we awake, open our eyes  and let the world pour into us, we can also others to experience this too.

We appreciate and thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. We take this step with all of you in our minds as it is our actions together that crystalise in a power that makes a change. Your donations is what will lead to the real difference. 

As always, peace to you all x

eventName: Ben and Josie give up alcohol for Sightsavers
story:
Sightsavers believes that no one should be blind from avoidable causes, and that people whose sight can’t be saved should live with dignity and independence.


There are 39 million blind people in the world, 80% of blindness can be prevented or cured, and around 90% of visually impaired people live in the world’s poorest countries.


Sightsavers tackle the main causes of avoidable blindness, and work to  educate, enable social inclusion, and help affected communities.


Watch the Sightsavers TV advert to see the faces of children when they receive a simple operation that enables them to see for the first time. It costs just £120, but that is beyond the reach of many in the poorest communities across the world.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Sightsavers is a much needed charity that operates across developing countries to prevent blindness.  Living in the developed world we  are incredibly lucky not to have to worry about the issues being tackled by Sightsavers.

There are 12 million people who are blind due to cataracts - this is entirely preventable, but in developing countries the medical help is not always available.  With the cataracts operation costing just £30 this should not happen in 2018.

They also work to fight several tropical diseases that cause blindness, including Trachoma and River Blindness.  The treatment for these is tablets - Sightsavers work to supply these around the world.

To help this charity I'm going to swim across the English Channel.  It's about 34 km (21.5 miles) across, and to add interest no wetsuits are allowed.  Some people smother themselves in goose fat, but surely that just attracts sharks, so I'll not be doing that.  Jellyfish are common - just have to be lucky to avoid those little monsters.  Crossing one of the world's busiest shipping lanes will add a few ups and downs to carry me along my way. 

Mostly I hope just to make it to France.  I don't have a target time, but expect to be swimming around 12 - 14 hours. 

My training has mostly been eating chocolate to build up fat to keep me warm, and I've done quite well - putting on 12kg since Christmas - I hope I can lose it after!  I've also been practicing swimming with plenty of long steady (slow) hours done in the pool.

I'll be swimming on my own, but there will be a boat next to me to keep me pointing in the right direction and to throw bottles of drink at me. 

Thanks very much for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page and for reading this far.

I would be really grateful if you would sponsor me for this swim.  The money you donate will go straight to Sightsavers and will be well spent on the issues mentioned.

Thanks a lot,

Philip.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Phoebe was born with very dense cataracts covering  both eyes, at just 8 weeks old she underwent surgery to both eyes. With fantastic opthalmolagists looking after her, she has been given the very best chance in leading her life with vision. 

We are fortunate enough to have access to an amazing eye hospital and fantastic doctors who have taken care of Phoebe since she was born. Sadly, not everyone is as lucky and there are children in the underdeveloped world, who’s sight cannot develop without this surgery. 

We want to pay it forward and help as many children who aren’t as fortunate as our little girl.

Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness around the world. £5 is all it takes to give the gift of sight to a child.

Our initial goal is to support  children around the world and give them the same chance to regain their vision as we were able to do for Phoebe.

Your donations are very much appreciated and will go directly to sightsavers. You’ll get some lovely homemade cake in return 🍰❤️🍰

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
What's my challenge?

  • I'll be trekking up Mount Kilimanjaro (Tanzania) ideally to the summit at 5.895km above sea level (and down again) this June, 2018, covering about 62km over 6 days and 5 nights. Challenge accepted!

Which charity am I fund raising for?

  • Sightsavers.  A UK registered charity founded in England in 1950.
  • I've been donating to Sightsavers for a couple of years.
  • All donations will go to Sightsavers - I will be paying all expenses, either directly or through Action Challenge which will be organising the trek.

What does Sightsavers do?

  • Sightsavers aims to prevent avoidable blindness by funding operations for people who need them, training eye care workers and surgeons. Through community volunteers in developing countries, Sightsavers arranges for medication to be distributed to prevent blinding diseases. Treating among other conditions:
  • cataracts - in developing countries it’s a huge problem for children (as well as older people) - cataracts are thought to cause up to 60% of blindness in parts of Africa, and 20 million people worldwide are blind because of the condition,
  • neglected tropical diseases (parasitic and bacterial infections that affect more than a billion people worldwide, causing severe and often lifelong physical impairment and affect some of the world’s poorest people, trapping them in a cycle of poverty and social isolation),
  • refractive errors.
  • Sightsavers also supports equality for people with disabilities and campaigns and advocates for change.
What will the trek entail?

  • Day 1: trek 11km through lush rain forest to Machame camp at 3km above sea level. 
  • Day 2: trek 5km across moorland but gaining altitude by making camp at 3.8km above sea level. 
  • Day 3 entails an 11km trek across barren semi-dessert, reaching 4.6km in altitude before descending to 4km to make camp. 
  • Day 4: after a 9km trek we sleep at Barafu Camp at 4.7m high (“barafu” being Swahili for “ice”). 
  • Day 5: starting at midnight, we start the 5km trek to the Uhuru Peak (Swahili for “freedom”) 5.9km above sea level to see the sun rise, before descending to camp for the last night on Kilimanjaro.
  • Day 6: descending down the Mweka route to a well deserved beer and much needed shower!

How your donation can help?

  • For every £1 Sightsavers receives, including donated supplies, 91p goes on vital charity work and the remainder helps grow awareness and funding.
  • £5 could help 14 people for trachoma, 
  • £28 could protect a whole community against river blindness, 
  • £50 could provide a cataract operation to restore a childs sight.
﻿﻿And finally...

  • whilst I’m concerned about how I’ll handle the altitude on Kilimanjaro, I think my biggest challenge will be the fund raising. 
  • Thank you kindly for making time to visit my fund raising page (and reading my “essay”) and donating to Sightsavers to help make a change. 

Bhav.


P.s. 

  • If you’d like to leave your name I’d like to thank you personally.  I hope to update this page (and social media eventually) with progress updates nearer June. 

How you can donate efficiently:

  • UK tax payers can tick the Gift Aid box to ensure that JustGiving recovers the tax you’ve already paid on your donation for Sightsavers.
  • Please also keep a record of your donation for your Self Assessment tax return where applicable.
  • Donations from companies may not recover Gift Aid, but may be a business expense.

A web link to Sightsavers home page is further down...

story:
I will be undertaking a mammoth trek of 100km from London to Brighton in 24 hours. Some of you may remember I did this some years ago, but  completed the trek slower than my target time of 24 hours, due to awful weather and blisters the size of cocktail sausages. So a few years older, fatter and creakier, I have foolishly decided to have another go. 

Now my knees, back and ankles aren't so good, and I often make an "oof" noise when I get out of a low chair, but I am determined to finish in under 24 hours. I will be supporting Sightsavers, whose work fighting avoidable blindness and supporting people with disabilities I whole-heartedly believe in (I do work for them, after all).

So please give generously if you can, and take comfort in the fact that I haven't asked you to do this with me...

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m running the Conakry 12km again but this year to raise money for equipment for the SOGUE (meaning “sun”) blind school in Conakry.  The school was founded in 2002 and has 45 children - 15 girls and 30 boys.  The funds raised will buy learning tools such as braille paper, slates, letters, styluses and cubarithmes. With these we hope to contribute a little more light to the lives of visually impaired children in this developing country.  

As ever I thought hard about  running the half marathon, but Conakry’s 30+ degree heat and high humidity beats me every time and I’ve decided that 12km is still my limit. 

I’ll be contributing through Sightsavers UK who have agreed to collect your contributions and donate them specifically to the SOGUE school. In Guinea Sightsavers are working on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) some of which are diseases of the  eyes such as River Blindness. I know the Sightsavers team here well and am certain that they will squeeze the maximum value for the school from even the smallest amounts of support.  

Sightsavers UK’s overall mission is to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote equality of opportunity for people with disabilities, and they work in over 30 countries.  In 2017 they hit a record 1 billion NTD treatments  across the world - a phenomenal milestone.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Along with four great friends, all racing towards our forties, I have
taken the decision to run the Brighton Marathon and tick off a massive
challenge from my bucket list.

﻿I have decided to run the marathon for Sightsavers.  This is a
fantastic charity which was incredibly well publicised when I was a child, but less known today.  They work tirelessly to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote the rights of people with disabilities in less developed countries.

There are so many deserving charities, it was hard to choose who to support.  One of the main factors which helped me decide to run for this charity was that a family member used to work for Sightsavers.  Last year at the age of just 31 she was diagnosed with cancer and sadly passed away.  Please support Sight Savers in her memory and "live like CT".

I am not a runner.  I'm certainly not built for it, so please, please, please, dig deep and sponsor me for this great cause.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
I did it! The picture above is at mile 17 with just 9 miles to go. Blow by blow account in updates section below but it was not pretty with a hamstring injury and cramps and 80 minutes slower than my last attempt in 2014. But together we have raised over £7,400 (inclusive of gift aid) for Sightsavers which is truly amazing. Thank you so much. 

I turned 60 this February and wanted to celebrate this by running to support this great charity. This was my sixth London marathon since my wife and kids told me (with good justification) in my mid-40s that I was going to seed so I am indebted to them. 

As a general surgeon who has served in a Kenyan mission hospital I've witnessed first-hand the devastating damage that blindness can do to individuals and communities but also know how effective and cheap preventive and curative measures are. 

As CEO of Christian Medical Fellowship I'm deeply committed to healthcare in the developing world.

In five previous marathons between 2004 and 2014  friends and colleagues generously helped me to raise over £25,000 for Whizz Kidz, Alzheimer's Society, Down's Syndrome, Help the Hospices and Christian Blind Mission so this latest effort brings the grand total to over £30,000. 

If you still want to give it is not too late.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As many of you know I walked the 192 mile Coast to Coast path in September 2015 raising £2500 for Sightsavers.

I chose this charity as in 2015 I had laser eye surgery which meant I didn’t have to wear glasses anymore. I realised how lucky I was to have the choice and money to just make a decision and go to have the treatment unlike many others who have to live with their vision impairment.

When I read about A Million Miracles I felt the need to help as much as I could. Sightsavers work is very inspiring.

My Coast to Coast walk was an organised group that I joined with my friend Elizabeth. There were 14 of us in all and we soon became very good friends spending 14 days walking and chatting about anything and everything to while away the long hours across the Lake District, Yorkshire Dales and North York Moors. It was during these chats that 2 people, separate of each other suggested I take up running. I poo pooed them and said I had never even run across the road for a bus and there was no way I could go running but it stuck with me and I kept thinking about it.

When I got home I felt physically and mentally strong after walking 192 miles even though my feet felt like horse’s hooves.

I decided not to let the strength disappear and so I downloaded the app, Couch to 5K, and tentatively started the first 1 minute run that nearly killed me. Soon I was running a bit more every week and eventually I reached the 5K (30 minutes) and I cried. Not from pain but from the sense of achievement.

I quickly decided to down load the app 5k-10k and set off to double my distance over a period of months. Eventually cracking the 10K distance.

At this point I didn’t know if I should continue as I was worried I was too old and would destroy my knees. But my sensible head went out of the window as I downloaded the app 10K-21K and started to work towards the half marathon. I live in Ealing and there is a very good half marathon every year in September which goes right past the front of my house. I usually go out every year to clap the runners past, never dreaming that I would ever be able to do such a thing. (As of September 24th 2017 I have now completed that half marathon in 2 hours and 8 minutes and am very happy with that time for my first effort.)

I then received an email from Margaret (one of the ladies who was on the coast to Coast walk) to say that her friend Karen was going to be running in the London Marathon in April 2017 for charity and would we consider sponsoring her. Karen was very special to us, she was not just any old friend of Margaret, she went out of her way to drive across the UK with a box of homemade chocolate brownies and a bottle of fizz for us all on our last day. She met us in a small village about 2 hours walk from Robin Hood’s Bay (our final destination) with the brownies to share out amongst us to give us all a chocolate boost and then drove on to Robin Hood’s Bay with the fizz and shared it all out with a glass for each of us to celebrate our wonderful achievement as we dipped our toes in the water. What a wonderful friend.

Of course, I sponsored Karen, after all, one good turn deserves another even after one and a half years had gone by. I then spent all of Sunday morning trying to spot her on TV in the marathon. It was at this point that I decided I could do this. I could run that marathon too as I watched everyone running the course. So here I am with a place and am absolutely petrified, what have I done? But I WILL do this and hope to raise a good sum for Sightsavers and all those eyesights that will be restored to people who have lost hope.

I hated sports at school and was always useless. Sports day was my biggest nightmare as I ran around hurdles and under the high jump and would hide in the toilets. Who would think that in my 60th year I would attempt to do such a thing as run the London marathon? I wish my teachers could see me now.

Last year I ran in my first ever race, the Osterley 10K. it was 26 degrees that morning but I completed it in literally seconds over the hour and I was the proud owner of my first ever running medal. (I went to bed in it that night and woke up with the medal part under my armpit ) I have since hung it up to remind me of what i can achieve when I decide to do something. My Ealing Half marathon was run in 20 degrees and full sunshine but I completed it and now have a second medal which I also wore to bed that night!! I can feel a tradition starting here.

At the beginning of February I also completed, with a personal best of 57 minutes, the London Winter 10k run with 20,000 other people, starting in Trafalgar Square and running basically to St Paul's and back round the streets of London. It was freezing cold but so much fun and honestly, I felt like I would have liked to turn round and do it all again when I got to the end. I wanted to experience what it was like to run with so many people in London before the big MARATHON day.

I have now completed the hottest London marathon on record, 24.1 degrees officially, in a time I am really chuffed with, 4:59:17, a fraction under the 5 hour mark. It was challenging and hot but I was well trained (I had run 419 miles during the previous 5 months), well fuelled thanks to my lovely Craig and well hydrated due to no alcohol at all for at least a month before. I felt strong and determined and when it got tough around 23-24 miles I gave myself a good talking to and ran on to get over the line in just under the 5 hours which was my aim. 

I love my medal, its heavy and bears all the weight of the effort involved to obtain it. I will never forget that day for the rest of my life, I ran with a massive smile most of the way. Apologies in advance if you still see me wearing my medal now and again but I am chuffed to bits with it :)

I am now an official marathoner at the age of 59 and a half!!! xxx

I wrote a blog about my Coast to Coast walk if you want to read about my effort. How did I know that it would be the start of something much larger?

http://lozandherboots.blogspot.co.uk/

We decided to set up this page in memory of our Dad, George Kinross. Dad believed passionately in finding ways to support the world's poorest people. There are so many charities doing important development work; we have chosen Sightsavers because Dad was able to donate his corneas and hopefully save someone's sight. Sightsavers works in the world's poorest countries to prevent and treat avoidable blindness and to campaign for the rights of visually impaired people.

eventName: Alison goes alcohol free for January!
story:
Hi all I hope you all had a wonderful Christmas and New Year!

I have decided to give up alcohol for January in attempt to raise money for Sightsavers charity.

Did you know 75% of sight loss can be cured or prevented?! Imagine facing vision loss that could be cured or prevented.. but you are unable to get the help required due to your place of birth.

I was recently referred to hospital during an eyetest, without this intervention I may have risked losing my vision. I was sent to A&E by a lovely and very competent lady called Hannah at Vision Express Bury st Edmonds and was looked after very well by the NHS West Suffolk hospital where a diagnosis of viral meningitis was made. I am now home and I am under the care of the outpatient opthomology service. I was fortunate to get the help/care/treatment I needed, others born into poverty are not so lucky. Sightsavers can change lives of children and adults around the world, where there isn’t adequate healthcare services.

Sightsavers really do change lives. Every year, sightsavers support their partners to carry out millions of eye examinations and refer people for treatment to prevent blindness and restore sight.

Please donate generously if you can.. as you all know I am partial to a glass of wine, but it will be a pleasure to go without this month if it means I can raise some money for Sightsavers! 

If you can’t donate please take from this the importance of eye tests both routinely and if you notice any changes to vision or headaches etc.

Thanks for reading!!

Alison xxx

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Our brother, Geoff Pyke, died on Christmas Day after a short illness. Following a successful career as a chemical engineer, Geoff applied his considerable intellect to studying history and was finalising his PhD.  

Anne and Geoff loved to travel and visited many less developed countries where they saw the huge difference that organisations such as Sightsavers make to the quality of life. Relatively straightforward eye operations, such as the one Geoff had as a three year old, are beyond the means of so many families in developing countries. Sightsavers seeks to redress this balance.                                                                

Please join us in making donations in memory of Geoff to enable Sightsavers to continue this valuable work.

Thanks from Bill and Lin Pyke

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Shave Santa - get rid of that hairy bundle and be clean shaven - Lose the beard!


SightSavers - the reason ... for those that don't know, I am totally blind in my left eye after many attempts to save the sight following a Giant Retinal Tear that turned into a Retinal Detachment. The other eye, well, it has had an operation to save the sight and the fear of becoming completely blind (complete darkness with no light perception at all) lives with me every single day. I am lucky, I can still see, some people around the world do not and it is worst in developing countries that lack resources. It is for others that we live on this planet, to love others and care for them.

As a bit of fun and considering so many people see my chubby cheeks, my real life belly, my white hair, my love of wearing a red suit at Christmas and ... of course ... the white beard, I decided to try raising funds for charities:

- Shave Santa cause will raise funds for SightSavers International being a charity that helps prevent blindness, supports blind people and performs so many good functions in the developing world.

- Save Santa cause will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice.

The cause that raises the most amount of money will see me either Shave the Santa trade mark beard or Save the Santa trade mark beard. On the 22nd December this year, my face will either continue to look like Santa or it will be clean shaven!!!


This page is to raise funds for SightSavers International, to help prevent blindness and help people who are blind in developing countries around the world.

They need our help, love and support.


The beard has been with me for many years now and over the years has become very white. I have been quite attached to it!!!


As for the Save Santa cause ... from the start of my mum's illness, all the early symptoms and no-one knowing the reasons, through the diagnosis of Pancreatic Cancer, followed by the horrific last few weeks was one of the most upsetting times of our lives.

The Save Santa page will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice to care for so many more people nearing the end of their lives and support so many families. As for the Save Santa page, it will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice who provide care that words just don't do justice. The incredible care for my mum and the kindness shown to my whole family was something that we will always remember. The people at the Ardgowan Hospice are fantastic and the place itself is somewhere so many families turn to throughout the year every year. The support before, during and after is second to none.

So, you decide. Save or Shave Santa this year ... for a good cause. Vote by donating. The winner is not me not matter, it is two great charities and a bit of fun at the same time. It will be exciting to see what will happen. I personally just hope both charities receive some good amounts of money from people around the world; as for the beard, I wonder what I will look like come the New Year. All will be revealed and please share this page far and wide. I am willing to do whatever it takes to raise as much money as possible in memory of Mum - the bravest person I have ever loved xxx

story: As you know, Tom was a wonderful human being. He died of a heart attack whilst cycling in Kazakhstan in August this year.  In his memory, there will be a collection for the charity Sightsavers.  It is a charity he particularly favoured as his sight was so poor and he was always so careful of and dependent on his glasses.  Having been in Kenya for two years, he was keenly aware of how lucky we are in the UK to have the NHS to sort out eye problems and provide glasses for those that need them. Sightsavers is a UK-based international charity which fights avoidable blindness, and promotes equal opportunities for visually impaired people. It also supports surgeons in their cataract operations in the field in countries on many continents, including Africa.

story:
If you are looking at this page I have invited you to my 50th birthday party on June 16th. Instead of bringing me a present that I won't know what to do with on the night, I am asking everyone to give at least £5 to Sightsavers.  This is enough for them to restore sight to a child somewhere less fortunate than this. 

Just think about that for a moment.

If all 50 of you donate £5 to this page, 50 kids will see the sun catching a cobweb, or a rainbow, or their Mum's smile. That's quite a gift to give. 

I'd rather wake up to that thought on June 17th than a pile of presents.

You can always give more than £5 of course. 

And if you buy me a present as well, I'll forgive you :-)

THANK YOU 

Trainboy (and 50 kids who would stay blind otherwise)

story:
I got my first (Lion King) glasses when I was 8 and with a prescription of -8.5 my specs have long been my safety net. I was fortunate to grow up with optional extras to make life easier; clip-on sunglasses (I was cool), prescription swimming goggles, then contact lenses and even some creative Dad-inventions (old lenses stuck inside a snorkelling mask). A few months ago I went one better and benefitted from the incredible technology of Laser Eye Surgery. Within 3 days I was deemed legal to drive without visual aid (pretty hard to comprehend when you've lived through -8.5).

Wearing glasses wasn't an issue (unsurprisingly I was used to it), but I always felt vulnerable to any situation in which they could be ripped away. In an emergency my confidence and independence would instantly be gone. And yet too many people don't even have the privilege of a simple pair of glasses or access to the everyday eye care that we can take for granted. I feel extremely fortunate to have grown up shortsighted in my world, yet others are unnecessarily losing their sight to treatable conditions or struggling with everyday activities.

As I celebrate my first spec-free birthday in over 20 years, I'm asking friends and family to donate towards my fundraising campaign to give others the gift of sight. Thank you!
title: A gift of sight

story:
Say goodbye to our amazing flowing hair. 

Three of us here at Traveleyes - a tour company helping the visually impaired see the world - are shaving our heads for Sightsavers who do fantastic work all over the world. 

There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80 per cent of blindness can be cured or prevented. That’s 31.2 million people who are blind when they needn’t be.

Sightsavers want to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind or disabled to live independently.

So please give generously through our just giving page and remember to add gift aid.

We will put up a video on Facebook and YouTube so please make sure you like and subscribe to watch the shaving happen.

https://www.facebook.com/traveleyesltd
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC6yFbJDy43RPNfgUxrF1rhg

Thank you so much for your support.

The Traveleyes Team.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Hellooo everyone! 

It's been a long time since I've been involved in any sort of fundraising events! Here I am, challenging myself to do a skydive (Yes I mean it!) to raise fund for sightsavers! 

Sightsavers is an international organisation that helps to combat blindness and provide support to people especially those who are less fortunate. Most importantly, sightsavers provide services to partially sighted or the blind to help them achieve a better quality of life they deserve. 

Sight and vision is important because it allows us to connect to the surroundings and to perceive beauty that nature has to offer. They also keep us safe.

Right now 39 million people in the world suffer from blindness - and 80% of them are potentially curable and preventable if they have the right resources.

Why not help make a difference? Help change the lives of people who are at risk of losing their sight.

Thank you!

When I reach the target - challenge accepted!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I've been growing my hair for almost 2 years now but on the 12th May I will be getting it all shaved off - who knows what's under there?!

I chose to raise money for Sightsavers for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the cause is something close to my heart; although not blind by any stretch, without corrective surgery for my short sight I'd be unable to drive or even recognise people standing a few meters away. If I'd been born in a different part of the world I'd have really struggled with everyday life due to my poor vision.

Secondly, I'm really keen on giving effectively - basically getting as much 'bang for your buck' when donating to charities. Sightsavers score highly in this regard as 91% or all money donated goes straight to helping people with sight issues and much of the treatments are very cost effective.

Any and all donations are massively appreciated and will be going to an extremely worthwhile cause.

Will be sure to share some before and after pics with all sponsors!

Thanks,

Stef﻿

﻿﻿

eventName: Shaving my head for children with Trachoma.
story:
I will be shaving my head on May 18th 2017 in order to raise money for people suffering from Trachoma. Trachoma is a bacterial eye infection that makes the eyelids turn inwards until your eyelashes scrape against the surface of your eyes. Slowly, you go blind. However, this disease is easily preventable with antibiotics, but many cannot afford or access antibiotics. People affected with this are usually living in rural areas with no direct connection to a health centre and have no effective methods of transport. Even a small amount of money can buy a lot of antibiotics and treat a lot of people. 

Many thanks for considering giving to this cause.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
We, as a family would like to fundraise for Sightsavers in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai. Mariyah was diagnosed with Ewing's Sarcoma, an extremely aggressive form of cancer at the age of 7 and a half and engaged in a battle with it up until the age of 16, where she endured a plethora of treatments including chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery in both conventional and experimental variations. She was subjected to an overwhelming bombardment of hardship, pain and suffering throughout her years but despite that she continued to plough on with her strong character, will and determination. 

The tumour originated in her femur and then continued to grow and metastasise around her body but she continued to fight it at every step of its progression. She endured inhumane amounts of pain, sickness and suffering caused by combination of the disease and the side effects of the rudimentary treatments that exist today. These did not phase her up until December 2016 when she was experiencing severe headaches and blurry vision and we were told that the cancer had metastasised into her brain which is extremely rare for her form and that it was applying pressure to her eyes, thus distorting her vision. She underwent radiotherapy which was unsuccessful and we were not able to contain the tumour within her. It continued to colonise her brain and eventually it grew on her optic nerves and she effectively lost her vision. 

Mariyah had endured every side effect and possible manifestation of pain but it did not defeat her, however when she lost her eyesight, she was absolutely distraught. Her character had changed, her will wasted away and she began to lose herself and eventually so would we. For Mariyah, her vision was her connection to the outside world, even when she was cornered by the unstoppable forces of nature within her, it allowed her to see the comforting smile of her parents faces or even the photos that would evoke her favourite memories that would provide her with the hope and thus determination to fight; however when this connection was severed she was defeated as she entered the dark abyss of the end of her life. 

Sadly, she lost her battle on the 19th of April 2017. However, before she had passed she had heard about Sighsavers and their pledge to treat blind children and restore their vision by removing their cataracts. When she heard that it would only cost £4 per eye, she immediately wanted to contribute to restore the vision of as many children as she could as she was enraged that it could be done so easily. Even though she knew that her vision could not be restored, she wanted to impact the lives of those that could be treated as she had endured their pain. She wanted to add this extremely personal pledge to her portfolio of charitable work but unfortunately she was not able to do so. Therefore, we would like to carry out Mariyah's wish to pledge and continue her profound impact on this planet by giving the gift of sight.
title: Fundraising in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Phoebe Woollcombe's JustGiving page.

Phoebe, who died suddenly of cancer in November, was always the most charitable of souls. She gave to dozens of charities, worked in a charity shop for years, and organized the Red Cross charity flag sellers in her parish for 30 years, all unpaid and out of the goodness of her large heart. 

But Sightsavers was especially close to that heart, the one cause above all others that she wanted to support. For her, blindness was the most terrible of afflictions, and Sightsavers' mission to eliminate avoidable blindness and to make the world a fairer place for people with such disabilities was something that deserved the widest possible support.

And while she loved flowers, she always thought it wrong that money would be lavished on flowers for a funeral (which wouldn't benefit the deceased), when it could be spent to much better effect and benefit far more by being given to a good cause such as Sightsavers.

Phoebe was not a great one for computers, always preferring handwritten letters, phone calls and face-to-face contact, but she diligently attended a computer class for years, learning (just about) how to read and write emails. She was a great pragmatist, however, and she did accept that, even if it was all gobbledygook to her, the internet could be harnessed for good purposes. Hence this page – and the comparable one for her late, much missed husband Dick (https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/richardwoollcombe) in aid of the Alzheimer's Society – had her blessing, in the hopes that it would help her precious cause of Sightsavers. 

So, whether you knew Phoebe and want to give something in her memory, or whether you think Sightsavers is an admirable cause and deserves support, thank you for whatever you can give.

PS  Why is this page called Phoebe's Online Egg Round? Simple: as anyone who lived near her will know, once a week she would go round the local village selling eggs from her hens to friends and neighbours. She always called this her egg round, and it became very much a social event, with her driving home full to the gills after 15 cups of tea and endless chat. She also milked it for all she was worth when she was selling flags for the Red Cross. This page is very much in the same shameless spirit, hence the name!

Finally, here's the official blurb:

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Dr Johan von Schreeb arrived in Guiuan in the east of Samar island yesterday, an area devastated by Typhoon Haiyan and where Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) emergency team is setting up its medical services and treating patients. They are creating what will be an integrated provision of mobile clinics, reaching out to the more isolated parts of the coast and islands, and outpatient services in the town of Guiuan itself. Guiuan had almost all of its buildings destroyed and the local hospital is not functioning. MSF will be providing water and sanitation services as soon as possible and will also assist with shelter.  

Building a temporary hospital is a priority as only minor surgery can be provided at present. Meanwhile the queues are growing, as tetanus jabs have to be administered to prevent the further infection and to help patients suffering with pneumonia and diarrhoea.

charity.name: Médecins Sans Frontières (UK)
story:
The word EBOLA evokes a different feeling for each one of us... for some it is imminent death, for others it is the fear of death, misery, poverty and the stealth killer. ... so many emotions attached to this word that symbolises a horrible disease.

Ebola is but a river in the Congo and I hear myself say… a river brings life, prosperity but Ebola brings an undignified fight for life and for most it brings death!

This is my Ebola journey - I like many Sierra Leoneans living abroad reacted to this tragedy in the same way as the cumbersome WHO machine and the inept local governments of the region.  We have all been too slow to react!   Most including myself thought it would go away quickly and someone else with more responsibility and leadership would solve this problem.  What could we do? Whatever little contribution would be but a tiny drop in the ocean! But this is where I am wrong so as I now live and breathe Ebola through the media, family and friends, I believe it is time  for me to be a ' little Ebola activist' and join the war against Ebola!
And to us Sierra Leoneans, this is a war! My generation lived through a civil war as young adults so we know the effects and the trauma and how our lives changed permanently.  Only this time our lives are not being ruined by a bunch of renegade men that have a chopping ‘fettish’ but a virus, a little squiggly tadpole like ‘thingie’ that wreaks havoc on its victims. Ebola just creeps up on you!  You can feel it drawing closer as people around you start to die, first it is on the other side of village, then it is a couple of streets away, then it is at the bottom of your road and finally a couple of doors away but you have no idea if and when it will grab you and suck the life out of you.  We are human so we cannot survive in isolation so Ebola’s victims can only wait….(don’t worry, ebola is not coming to a street near you!)

Of all the Ebola stories, it is Patrick Sawyers' story that struck me the most... because of when and where he fell ill, the people who he infected and his was a tragedy of the unknown.  The Nigerian doctors that survived have been very eloquent in giving an insight into surviving this virus, I feel they have given a voice to the tragedy that is Ebola  as many of the victims are poor uneducated people who rely on the health workers who treat them to tell of their suffering and undignified death.  The other educated survivors… well their’s is a different story!

For those of you that don't know Patrick’s story this is how I understood it

Day1:  He called his sister for a chat as he had not heard from her in a while and she mentioned that she felt a bit poorly.
 Day 4:  He called her to see how she was doing and she says I am getting worse but it is probably malaria so I have taken some medication and should be better soon.
 Day 6:  He gets a call for his brother in law to say his sister is very ill in hospital so he rushes there to see her.
  Day 7: His sister is DEAD and Patrick has contracted Ebola probably as he hugged his sibling for the last time. How can we not hold our loved ones when they are most in need?

This was in the early days of Ebola and no one fully appreciated this nasty virus and he had no idea that he was going to die within a few weeks and infect a number of Nigerian health workers. His story is so simple but just one of the many Ebola stories and there are many such stories that tell of family heartbreak, villages devastated and so many babies and children…. What is their fate?!

My goodness!!! You have got to the end….thank you for taking the time to read this. You have received this e-mail because either my husband, daughters' or I know you professionally or personally so if this email touches you and you would like to help my little fight against a BIG enemy(well a squiddgy little ropey thing) then I would be so grateful.

If you decide to contribute then I implore you to forward to a couple of friends/family with a note asking them to help join my fight against Ebola. Please also ask your companies to contribute to MSF as there is always money in the kitty for charities.

To help me in my little fight please either:

Click Donate to fund Medicins san Frontieres(MSF UK) work in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia.
MSF is a charity that I have always supported. I am in awe of their volunteers and what they have done round the world in many emergencies! See below for more information from them. You can also text SLEB76 and £10 to 70070 to give £10(I tested,it works).  I am hoping you can give more but every little helps.

OR

Sometimes we don’t like the big charities, we don’t feel like they reach the little people immediately and some have huge costs(not MSF I might add) so I am raising a fund that I am personally accountable for.  I hope this will help people directly and quickly when they are in desperate need during this crisis. The money could be used to buy basic sanitation equipment, help struggling families to buy food but most importantly to help care for orphaned babies and children temporarily or you can give these things to me and I will organise a shipment.  The needs are endless so it would be what little we can do – If you would like to contribute in this way then please e-mail me on jaxperret@hotmail.com and I’ll get back in touch.  I will set up a facebook page to keep you involved with this process.

All I can say is THANK YOU! THANK YOU! and THANK YOU!

More information from MSF

Costs

1/ Cost of equipment for one health worker : £39  2/ Cost of training for one health worker :  £40 

3/ Cost of bed for one patient : £57  4/ Cost of forty chemical resistant gloves : £104 

5/ Cost of two pairs of rubber boots : £20 

MSF is very cautious in its fundraising activities for emergency appeals and works continuously with operational staff to ensure that all funds raised are within our budget for expenditure. Given the scale of the emergency and the consequences that it has had on the healthcare system in the countries I do believe that we will be continue to provide medical care once the outbreak is over. For example, we are in the process of planning a mass distribution of mosquito nets, anti-malaria drugs and oral rehydration salts in Sierra Leone in order to ensure that other illnesses are not being ignored as a result of the Ebola outbreak.

I believe we will continue to carry out similar activities and provide primary healthcare until the Ministry of Health in each of the countries is able to resume providing adequate medical care.

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is an independent humanitarian medical aid organisation. We are committed to providing medical aid where it is most needed, regardless of race, religion, politics or gender and also to raising awareness of the plight of the people we help.
charity.name: Médecins Sans Frontières (UK)
story:
I’m fundraising for Medecins Sans Frontieres - Doctors Without
Borders (MSF), an international charity that delivers lifesaving medical care to the people who need it most - regardless of where they are - or whether their stories have hit the headlines.

If you haven’t heard of them, here’s a cool link about their
incredible work - https://www.msf.org.uk/msf-videos.

More than 90 percent of their funding comes from people like
you and me. This is important because it means they don’t need to take money from governments, which allows them to remain independent, act quickly and go where the need is greatest.

For example, it meant that MSF was the first organisation to
respond to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa and swiftly scaled up operations when the disease spread. It meant they could respond within hours to the devastating typhoon in the Philippines, and are often working in forgotten crises in countries like South Sudan and Democratic Republic of Congo.

Private donations mean they can send medical teams to help people
in unstable situations like the current conflict in Yemen, Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as to many other countries around the world.

It would mean so much to me and MSF if you donated.

Many, many thanks

charity.description: Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) is an independent humanitarian medical aid organisation. We are committed to providing medical aid where it is most needed, regardless of race, religion, politics or gender and also to raising awareness of the plight of the people we help.
charity.name: Médecins Sans Frontières (UK)
story:
You may be aware that my brother and I are fairly enthusiastic runners. We both enjoy the physical and personal rewards - it is even better to claim these rewards side-by-side. However, a marathon requires an incredible amount of effort and training, the level of which is reflected in performance. Having previously completed two marathons each, we are both aware of the perseverance and commitment involved. Therefore, we seek your help in motivating us towards the realisation of our goals. To drive us to push ourselves.
To really make it possible for us to achieve more than we have before.
Both of us have a desire to achieve a new personal best, and we have our own personal goal times for completion. Our aspirations will require more training than either of us have previously attempted.

However, to do it in aid of a charity we are both inspired by and passionate about would make all the difference: when we're struggling through the last 6 miles, the knowledge that we are not struggling alone will keep our feet pounding forwards.

Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors without Borders) provides essential medical support to over 60 countries across the world. They truly live their name: your nationality is not what matters to them, but your cry for help. Their teams enter locations, often stricken by humanitarian disaster, where medical aid is most needed. They are a charity with a commitment to independence, impartiality, and accountability; by assessing what they do, they perform their best. The human network of health professionals working for MSF collectively help millions of people worldwide every year. For more information on MSF: https://www.msf.org.uk/

As a student nurse, I can personally relate and empathise with the nurses working for MSF. Nurses form the backbone of institutions such as the NHS, and they undoubtedly provide an essential service within MSF. My connection to MSF nurses, through the similarity of our profession, gives the charity personal relevance and deepens my support for their cause.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

To mark the end of Rentokil Initial's best ever fundraising year for Malaria No More UK and celebrate in style Rentokil Initial colleagues are invited to:

‘Pimp my Van’ and ‘Pimp my Desk’!

Rentokil Initial’s Fundraising Christmas Countdown

Please use this page to pay in your fundraising donations for Pimp My Van, Pimp My Desk and Pimp Your Manager. Please include details of your name or Rentokil Initial UK branch or business area with details of your pimping activity in the comments box.

charity.name: MALARIA NO MORE UK
story:
Hi everyone! My name is Shirley and I'm a 23 year old girl from London! In October of this year I took a trip to Ghana with my mum, to visit family, as we hadn't been back there in so long! It's such a wonderful place and I enjoyed my time there! But during my last few days, I contracted Malaria. It sort of crept up on me as I didn't even come across any mosquito bites, and I was taking anti-malarial tablets. I remember sitting with my family at an event, and feeling a little ill, and so I excused myself to the restroom, and I guess that's when the symptoms started. I was sick and felt so weak. When I explained this to my mum, and told her that I felt feverish (hot one minute, cold the next), she immediatly took me to the hospital. I saw the doctor and took some tests, and the results came back positive for malaria. I remember thinking, why me? Lucky for me, my mum was quick to make the decision to take me to the doctor. I recieved a few injections and medicine, and was told to finish the course of medicine over the following days. I was due to travel back to the UK that same day, and even though I was dreading the long plane ride, I just wanted to be home. It wasn't a pleasant journey as I cried half of the time, but when I got home, my mum put me in bed, and I was comfortable enough to rest. I was in bed for a whole week, but thankfully I recovered fully after that.

I can say that I am very fortunate to have been through that and recover, as some people aren't as lucky.

Malaria is a serious but preventable and treatable disease, but it claims the life of a child every minute. However, serious malaria cases can be reduced by providing mosquito nets, tests and medicines.

That's where a charity like Malaria No More UK comes in. I came across them and was very impressed with the work that they do to help people who may not have access to treatment or preventable measures for Malaria.

So I wanted to raise as much money as I could, with the help of my friends on the internet, to donate to their cause. If you're here reading this, thank you for visiting this page. And if you feel compelled to give, even as little as £1, I know that it would go a long way, and eventually help those people in need.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
